It has a blocky subconchoidal fracture, and is less fissile than shale. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011). Use of marl as a lithology should be avoided as it refers to unlithified marlstone.

concepts.label: massive sulfide
concepts.definition: A rock comprising abundant sulfide minerals, commonly making up at least 60 % of the mineral assemblage.

concepts.label: melilitolite
concepts.definition: An ultramafic intrusive rock consisting essentially of melilite, pyroxene and olivine, otherwise uncategorized. Now defined as a general term for intrusive rocks in the melilite-bearing rocks classification. Definition from Le Maitre et al. (2005, p. 110). Specific names apply based on the percentages of different mineral phases (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 11).

concepts.label: igneous melilitic
concepts.definition: A group name for ultramafic intrusive rocks that consist essentially of melilite, pyroxene and olivine. The term is reserved for rocks that contain greater than 10% modal melilite, and, if feldspathoids are present, melilite > feldspathoid; modal content of mafic minerals (M) is usually greater than 90%. Melilites are honey-coloured minerals with the general formula (Na,Ca)₂(Mg,Al)(Si,Al)₂O₇. Definitions adapted from Le Maitre et al. (2005, p. 11) and Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

concepts.label: melilitolite; undivided
concepts.definition: A demonstrably ultramafic intrusive rock consisting essentially of melilite, pyroxene and olivine, otherwise uncategorized. GSWA usage of this term is restricted to rocks that are partially weathered or are identified using remote sensing imagery, and the use of the related code/notation is limited to GSWA's Explanatory Notes System.

concepts.label: meta-andesite
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed intermediate volcanic rock, usually porphyritic, derived from a protolith consisting of plagioclase (frequently zoned from labradorite to oligoclase), pyroxene, hornblende and/or biotite. Igneous protolith defined modally in QAPF fields 9 and 10, and, if modes are not available, chemically in TAS field O2 (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 56). GSWA's rock classification scheme prefers the use of volcanic terminology for any igneous rock formed on or near the Earth's surface, i.e. for those hypabyssal or subvolcanic rocks such as dykes, sills, and cryptodomes that are demonstrably both spatially and temporally associated with extrusive volcanic rocks.

concepts.label: meta-anorthosite
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed leucocratic intrusive rock derived from a protolith consisting essentially of plagioclase commonly with small amounts of pyroxene. Igneous protolith defined modally in QAPF field 10 and in the gabbroic rock classification of Le Maitre et al. (2005, p. 22 and 24).

concepts.label: meta-arkose
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed rock derived from a siliciclastic sedimentary protolith rich in feldspar and with grain size between 0.0625 and 2 mm.

concepts.label: metasedimentary siliciclastic: psammite
concepts.definition: A group name for metamorphosed rocks derived from a medium-grained siliciclastic sedimentary protolith (grain size between 0.0625 and 2 mm), i.e. the metamorphosed equivalent of a sandstone. Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 188) identify psammite as a restricted-use term, and define it as "... a term for a sedimentary rock composed of sand-sized particles. It has also been used locally for the metamorphosed equivalent of these sedimentary rocks, that is, metamorphic rocks with a low modal ratio of mica to quartz + feldspar (Tyrrell, Robertson). The SCMR recommends that it should be used only for sedimentary rocks and the term metapsammite should be used for the metamorphosed equivalents." Acknowledging entrenched practises, GSWA usage departs from this recommendation, and allows the use of psammite as a noun for a metamorphosed equivalent of sandstone lithologies (i.e. grain size between 0.0625 and 2 mm), as well as an adjective to qualify metamorphic rocks derived from these sedimentary types (e.g. pelitic schist).

concepts.label: meta-banded chert
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed banded chert.

concepts.label: meta-banded iron formation
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed banded iron-formation, i.e. a metamorphosed iron formation that shows marked banding (generally of iron-rich minerals and chert or fine-grained quartz).

concepts.label: meta-igneous rock
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed rock of igneous but otherwise unspecified origin, i.e. a rock for which an igneous protolith is interpreted but commonly too weathered or altered to make further distinctions.

concepts.label: meta-igneous
concepts.definition: A group name for rock types of metamorphosed igneous but otherwise unspecified origin, i.e. including both intrusive and extrusive types.

concepts.label: meta-iron formation
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed rocks derived from a chemical sedimentary protolith containing at least 15% iron of sedimentary origin.

concepts.label: meta-olivine gabbro
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed intrusive rock (or coarse-grained parts of extrusive successions), derived from a gabbro containing essential olivine. Igneous protolith defined modally in the gabbroic rock classification (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 119).

concepts.label: meta-pyroxene spinifex textured basalt
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed volcanic basaltic rock with recognisable pyroxene spinifex texture, i.e. an igneous texture consisting of needle-like pyroxene crystals usually forming a criss-crossing pattern, the result of rapid quenching from unusually high temperatures (cf. https://glossary.americangeosciences.org/term/spinifextexture). GSWA's rock classification scheme prefers the use of volcanic terminology for any igneous rock formed on or near the Earth's surface, i.e. for those hypabyssal or subvolcanic rocks such as dykes, sills, and cryptodomes that are demonstrably both spatially and temporally associated with extrusive volcanic rocks.

concepts.label: meta-quartz diorite
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed felsic intrusive rock derived from a protolith having the composition of diorite but with an appreciable amount of quartz, i.e. between 5 and 20% of the felsic minerals (defined modally in QAPF field 10*; Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 134).

concepts.label: meta-quartz latite
concepts.definition: A term originally used for a volcanic rock composed of phenocrysts of quartz, plagioclase, biotite and hornblende in a glassy matrix potentially of quartz and alkali feldspar. Now commonly used for volcanic rocks composed of alkali feldspar and plagioclase in roughly equal amounts, quartz and mafic minerals. Now defined modally in QAPF field 8* (Fig. 2.4, p. 22). Definition from Le Maitre et al. (2005, p. 135) GSWA's rock classification scheme prefers the use of volcanic terminology for any igneous rock formed on or near the Earth's surface, i.e. for those hypabyssal or subvolcanic rocks such as dykes, sills, and cryptodomes that are demonstrably both spatially and temporally associated with extrusive volcanic rocks.

concepts.label: meta-quartz trachyte
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed volcanic rock derived from a protolith consisting of phenocrysts of alkali feldspar and quartz in a cryptocrystalline or glassy matrix. Igneous protolith defined modally in QAPF field 7* (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 135). GSWA's rock classification scheme prefers the use of volcanic terminology for any igneous rock formed on or near the Earth's surface, i.e. for those hypabyssal or subvolcanic rocks such as dykes, sills, and cryptodomes that are demonstrably both spatially and temporally associated with extrusive volcanic rocks.

concepts.label: meta-ultramafic intrusive rock
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed rock consisting essentially of mafic minerals and derived from an ultramafic igneous (intrusive or coarse-grained extrusive) protolith, but otherwise uncategorized.

concepts.label: meta-igneous ultramafic intrusive
concepts.definition: A group name for metamorphosed intrusive lithologies or coarse-grained parts of extrusive successions that are composed chiefly of mafic minerals, i.e. derived from intrusive protoliths with M greater than or equal to 90% (cf. Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 153), where M represents the volume modal percentage of mafic and related minerals (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 4).

concepts.label: meta-ultramafic volcanic rock
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed igneous volcanic or volcaniclastic rock derived from a protolith composed chiefly of one or more ferromagnesian, dark-coloured minerals in its mode, but otherwise uncategorized (adapted from Glossary of geology, 5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011). Igneous protolith defined as a rock with M greater than 90%, where M represents the volume modal percentage of mafic and related minerals (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 4 and 153). GSWA's rock classification scheme prefers the use of volcanic terminology for any igneous rock formed on or near the Earth's surface, i.e. for those hypabyssal or subvolcanic rocks such as dykes, sills, and cryptodomes that are demonstrably both spatially and temporally associated with extrusive volcanic rocks.

concepts.label: meta-igneous ultramafic volcanic
concepts.definition: A group name for metamorphosed volcanic and volcaniclastic lithologies derived from protoliths composed chiefly of one or more ferromagnesian, dark-coloured minerals such as olivine, pyroxene, etc. in their mode, with the volume modal percentage of mafic and related minerals (M) greater than or equal to 90% (cf. Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 4).

concepts.label: meta-ultramafic volcaniclastic rock
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed ultramafic volcaniclastic rock consisting of either (a) pyroclastic detritus or (b) terrigenous volcanic detritus of epiclastic origin and with an overall mafic composition, but otherwise uncategorized. 'Volcaniclastic' includes all clastic volcanic materials formed by any process of fragmentation, dispersed by any kind of transporting agent, deposited in any environment, or mixed in any significant portion with non-volcanic fragments.

concepts.label: metabasalt
concepts.definition: A fine-grained metamorphosed mafic volcanic rock consisting essentially of calcic plagioclase and pyroxene. Igneous protolith defined modally in QAPF fields 9 and 10 (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 31). GSWA's rock classification scheme prefers the use of volcanic terminology for any igneous rock formed on or near the Earth's surface, i.e. for those hypabyssal or subvolcanic rocks such as dykes, sills, and cryptodomes that are demonstrably both spatially and temporally associated with extrusive volcanic rocks.

concepts.label: metabasaltic andesite
concepts.definition: A fine-grained metamorphosed mafic volcanic rock with plagioclase of variable composition and the ferromagnesian minerals more commonly found in basalts, e.g. olivine. Igneous protolith defined chemically in TAS field O1 (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 61). GSWA's rock classification scheme prefers the use of volcanic terminology for any igneous rock formed on or near the Earth's surface, i.e. for those hypabyssal or subvolcanic rocks such as dykes, sills, and cryptodomes that are demonstrably both spatially and temporally associated with extrusive volcanic rocks.

concepts.label: metacarbonate rock
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed rock consisting essentially of carbonate minerals and derived from a carbonate protolith, but otherwise uncategorized.

concepts.label: metacarbonate with lesser siliciclastic
concepts.definition: Metamorphosed carbonate rocks interleaved at outcrop scale with subordinate metamorphosed siliciclastic rocks.

concepts.label: metacarbonatite
concepts.definition: A collective term for a metamorphosed igneous (intrusive, extrusive or volcaniclastic) rock in which the protolith had a modal amount of primary carbonate minerals greater than 50%, but otherwise uncategorized (section 2.3, p. 10). (Cf. Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 68)

concepts.label: metacarbonatite granofels/hornfels
concepts.definition: A granofels/hornfels derived by (contact) metamorphism of a carbonatite, i.e. an igneous protolith containing a modal amount of primary carbonate minerals greater than 50%. See also definition of granofels/granofelsic structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 156); hornfels are granofels formed by contact metamorphism (Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 159).

concepts.label: metachert
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed chert.

concepts.label: metaconglomerate
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed rock derived from a siliciclastic sedimentary protolith with grain size greater than 2 mm, i.e. coarser than sand.

concepts.label: metasedimentary siliciclastic: psephite
concepts.definition: A group name for metamorphosed rocks derived from a sedimentary siliciclastic protolith with grain size greater than 2 mm, i.e. the metamorphosed equivalent of a conglomerate. Acknowledging entrenched practises, GSWA usage allows the use of psephite as a noun for a metamorphosed equivalent of conglomerate lithologies (i.e. grain size greater than 2 mm), as well as an adjective to qualify metamorphic rocks derived from these sedimentary types (e.g. psephitic schist).

concepts.label: metadacite
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed volcanic rock derived from a protolith composed of quartz and sodic plagioclase with minor amounts of biotite and/or hornblende and/or pyroxene (volcanic equivalent of granodiorite and tonalite). Igneous protolith defined modally in QAPF fields 4 and 5, and, if modes are not available, chemically in TAS field O3 (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 72). GSWA's rock classification scheme prefers the use of volcanic terminology for any igneous rock formed on or near the Earth's surface, i.e. for those hypabyssal or subvolcanic rocks such as dykes, sills, and cryptodomes that are demonstrably both spatially and temporally associated with extrusive volcanic rocks.

concepts.label: metadiorite
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed felsic intrusive rock derived from a protolith consisting of intermediate plagioclase, commonly with hornblende and often with biotite or augite. Igneous protolith defined modally in QAPF field 10 (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 73).

concepts.label: metadolerite
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed mafic intrusive rock (or coarse-grained part of extrusive successions) derived from a protolith intermediate in grain size between basalt and gabbro and composed essentially of plagioclase, pyroxene and opaque minerals with varying amounts of quartz and possibly olivine; often with ophitic texture. Igneous protolith defined modally in QAPF (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 74).

concepts.label: metadunite derived from intrusive rock
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed ultramafic igneous (intrusive or coarse-grained extrusive) rock consisting essentially of olivine. Igneous protolith defined modally in the ultramafic rock classification of Le Maitre et al. (2005, p. 28).

concepts.label: metadunite derived from volcanic rock
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed ultramafic volcanic rock consisting essentially of olivine. Igneous protolith defined modally in the ultramafic rock classification (cf. Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 74). In GSWA usage this term refers to a metamorphosed dunite identified as formed from fractionation within thick bodies of ultramafic volcanic or subvolcanic magmas. GSWA's rock classification scheme prefers the use of volcanic terminology for any igneous rock formed on or near the Earth's surface, i.e. for those hypabyssal or subvolcanic rocks such as dykes, sills, and cryptodomes that are demonstrably both spatially and temporally associated with extrusive volcanic rocks.

concepts.label: metafelsic rock
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed felsic rock of igneous but otherwise unspecified origin, i.e. a felsic rock for which an igneous protolith (intrusive, extrusive or volcaniclastic) is interpreted but commonly too weathered or altered to make further distinctions.

concepts.label: metafelsic volcanic rock
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed rock consisting essentially of felsic minerals and derived from a felsic volcanic protolith, but otherwise uncategorized. GSWA's rock classification scheme prefers the use of volcanic terminology for any igneous rock formed on or near the Earth's surface, i.e. for those hypabyssal or subvolcanic rocks such as dykes, sills, and cryptodomes that are demonstrably both spatially and temporally associated with extrusive volcanic rocks.

concepts.label: metafelsic volcaniclastic rock
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed volcaniclastic rock consisting of either (a) pyroclastic detritus or (b) terrigenous volcanic detritus of epiclastic origin and with an overall felsic composition, but otherwise uncategorized. 'Volcaniclastic' includes all clastic volcanic materials formed by any process of fragmentation, dispersed by any kind of transporting agent, deposited in any environment, or mixed in any significant portion with non-volcanic fragments.

concepts.label: metagabbro
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed intrusive rock (or coarse-grained parts of extrusive successions), derived from a protolith composed essentially of calcic plagioclase, pyroxene and iron oxides, with varying amounts of quartz and possibly olivine. Igneous protolith defined modally in QAPF field 10 (cf. Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 83).

concepts.label: metagabbronorite
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed mafic intrusive rock (or coarse-grained parts of extrusive successions) derived from a protolith consisting of calcic plagioclase and roughly equal amounts of clinopyroxene and orthopyroxene. Igneous protolith defined modally in the gabbroic rock classification (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 83).

concepts.label: metagranitic rock
concepts.definition: In GSWA usage, a generic term for a metamorphosed rock derived from an igneous intrusive protolith composed chiefly of one or more felsic, light-coloured minerals in its mode and with quartz modal content between 0 and 60%, otherwise uncategorized.

concepts.label: metagranodiorite
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed felsic intrusive rock derived from a protolith consisting essentially of quartz, sodic plagioclase and lesser amounts of alkali feldspar with minor amounts of hornblende and biotite. Igneous protolith defined modally in QAPF field 4 (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 86).

concepts.label: metahydrothermal chert
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed, fine-grained siliceous rock that precipitated originally from a hydrothermal fluid related to seafloor or sub-seafloor volcanism.

concepts.label: metakomatiite
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed ultramafic extrusive rock derived from lavas that crystallize from high temperature magmas with 18% to 32% MgO. Pillows, chilled flow-tops and spinifex textures are commonly preserved. Igneous protolith defined chemically in the TAS classification (cf. Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 98).

concepts.label: metakomatiitic basalt
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed member of the komatiite series derived from a volcanic rock characterized by MgO in the range 5–15%, typically displaying spinifex texture and evidence of rapid quenching of high-temperature magma (cf. Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 61) and this vocabulary for a definition of the igneous protolith. GSWA's rock classification scheme prefers the use of volcanic terminology for any igneous rock formed on or near the Earth's surface, i.e. for those hypabyssal or subvolcanic rocks such as dykes, sills, and cryptodomes that are demonstrably both spatially and temporally associated with extrusive volcanic rocks.

concepts.label: metalatite
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed rock derived from a protolith chemically lying between trachyte and andesite, i.e. derived from a volcanic rock composed of approximately equal amounts of alkali feldspar and sodic plagioclase. Igneous protolith defined modally in QAPF field 8 and, if modes are not available, chemically as the potassic variety of trachyandesite in TAS field S3 (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 101). GSWA's rock classification scheme prefers the use of volcanic terminology for any igneous rock formed on or near the Earth's surface, i.e. for those hypabyssal or subvolcanic rocks such as dykes, sills, and cryptodomes that are demonstrably both spatially and temporally associated with extrusive volcanic rocks.

concepts.label: metamafic intrusive rock
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed rock consisting essentially of mafic minerals and derived from a mafic intrusive protolith or from coarse-grained parts of extrusive successions, but otherwise uncategorized.

concepts.label: metamafic rock
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed mafic rock, i.e. the metamorphosed equivalent of an igneous intrusive, extrusive or volcaniclastic rock mainly consisting of mafic minerals for which an igneous protolith is interpreted but commonly too weathered or altered to make further distinctions (cf. Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p.170).

concepts.label: metamafic volcanic rock
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed rock consisting essentially of mafic minerals and derived from a mafic volcanic protolith, but otherwise uncategorized. GSWA's rock classification scheme prefers the use of volcanic terminology for any igneous rock formed on or near the Earth's surface, i.e. for those hypabyssal or subvolcanic rocks such as dykes, sills, and cryptodomes that are demonstrably both spatially and temporally associated with extrusive volcanic rocks.

concepts.label: metamafic volcaniclastic rock
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed volcaniclastic rock consisting of either (a) pyroclastic detritus or (b) terrigenous volcanic detritus of epiclastic origin and with an overall mafic composition, but otherwise uncategorized. 'Volcaniclastic' includes all clastic volcanic materials formed by any process of fragmentation, dispersed by any kind of transporting agent, deposited in any environment, or mixed in any significant portion with non-volcanic fragments.

concepts.label: metamonzodiorite
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed felsic intrusive rock derived from a protolith intermediate between monzonite and diorite. Igneous protolith defined modally in QAPF field 9 (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 113).

concepts.label: metamonzogranite
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed felsic intrusive rock derived from a monzogranite, i.e. from a variety of granite in QAPF field 3b having roughly equal amounts of alkali feldspar and plagioclase (cf. Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 113).

concepts.label: metamonzonite
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed felsic intrusive rock derived from a monzonite, i.e. an intrusive rock containing almost equal amounts of plagioclase and alkali feldspar with minor amphibole and/or pyroxene. Igneous protolith defined modally in QAPF field 8 (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 113).

concepts.label: metamorphic rock
concepts.definition: A metamorphic rock so deeply altered/weathered that no inference can be made as to the protolith and with no discernible structures.

concepts.label: metamorphic
concepts.definition: A group name for metamorphic rocks so deeply altered/weathered that no inference can be made as to the protolith and with no discernible structures.

concepts.label: metamorphosed hydrothermal rock
concepts.definition: A hydrothermal rock that has undergone metamorphism, otherwise uncategorized.

concepts.label: metanorite
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed mafic intrusive rock (or coarse-grained parts of extrusive successions) derived from a norite, i.e. a rock composed essentially of bytownite, labradorite or andesine and orthopyroxene. Igneous protolith defined modally in the gabbroic rock classification (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 117).

concepts.label: metapegmatite
concepts.definition: The metamorphosed equivalent of a pegmatite, i.e. an exceptionally coarse-grained igneous rock with interlocking crystals, usually found as irregular dykes, lenses, or veins, especially at the margins of batholiths and of granitic composition (cf. Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 125).

concepts.label: metaperidotite derived from intrusive rock
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed ultramafic igneous (intrusive or coarse-grained extrusive) rock consisting essentially of olivine, pyroxene and/or amphibole. Igneous protolith defined modally in the ultramafic rock classification of Le Maitre et al. (2005, p. 28).

concepts.label: metaperidotite derived from volcanic rock
concepts.definition: A collective term for metamorphosed ultramafic volcanic rocks derived from a protolith consisting essentially of olivine, pyroxene and/or amphibole. Igneous protolith defined modally in the ultramafic rock classification of Le Maitre et al. (2005, p. 28 and 126). In GSWA usage this term refers to a metamorphosed peridotite identified as formed from fractionation within thick bodies of ultramafic volcanic or subvolcanic magmas.

concepts.label: metapyroxenite derived from intrusive rock
concepts.definition: Metamorphic rock consisting of more than 90% modal pyroxene (Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 190), i.e. a metamorphosed ultramafic igneous (intrusive or coarse-grained extrusive) rock composed almost entirely of one or more pyroxenes and occasionally biotite, hornblende and olivine. Igneous protolith defined modally in the ultramafic rock classification of Le Maitre et al. (2005, p. 28).

concepts.label: metapyroxenite derived from volcanic rock
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed ultramafic volcanic or volcaniclastic rock derived from a protolith composed almost entirely of one or more pyroxenes (greater than 90% modal pyroxenes) and occasionally biotite, hornblende and olivine; igneous protolith defined modally in the ultramafic rock classification (cf. Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 28 and 134; Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 190). In GSWA usage this term refers to a metamorphosed pyroxenite identified as formed from fractionation within thick bodies of ultramafic volcanic or subvolcanic magmas.

concepts.label: metarhyodacite
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed volcanic rock derived from a protolith intermediate between rhyolite and dacite. Igneous protolith defined as consisting of phenocrysts of quartz, plagioclase and a few ferromagnesian minerals in a microcrystalline groundmass (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 137). GSWA's rock classification scheme prefers the use of volcanic terminology for any igneous rock formed on or near the Earth's surface, i.e. for those hypabyssal or subvolcanic rocks such as dykes, sills, and cryptodomes that are demonstrably both spatially and temporally associated with extrusive volcanic rocks.

concepts.label: metarhyolite
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed silicic volcanic rocks derived from a rhyolitic protolith, i.e. a rock consisting of phenocrysts of quartz and alkali feldspar, often with minor plagioclase and biotite, in a microcrystalline or glassy groundmass and having the chemical composition of granite. Igneous protolith defined modally in QAPF field 3 and, if modes are not available, chemically in TAS field R (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 137). GSWA's rock classification scheme prefers the use of volcanic terminology for any igneous rock formed on or near the Earth's surface, i.e. for those hypabyssal or subvolcanic rocks such as dykes, sills, and cryptodomes that are demonstrably both spatially and temporally associated with extrusive volcanic rocks.

concepts.label: metasandstone
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed rock derived from a siliciclastic sedimentary protolith with grain size between 0.0625 and 2 mm.

concepts.label: metasedimentary rock
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed rock of sedimentary but otherwise unspecified origin, i.e. a rock for which a clastic or chemical/biochemical derivation cannot be conclusively established (e.g. due to weathering ).

concepts.label: metasedimentary
concepts.definition: A group name for metamorphosed rocks of sedimentary but otherwise unspecified origin, i.e. a rock for which a clastic or chemical/biochemical derivation cannot be conclusively established.

concepts.label: metasiliciclastic rock
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed rock derived from a siliciclastic protolith, i.e. from silicon-bearing (in the form of quartz and silicates), clastic non-carbonate rocks, but otherwise uncategorized. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011)

concepts.label: metasiltstone/metamudstone/metashale
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed rock derived from a siliciclastic sedimentary protolith with grains less than 0.0625 mm in size.

concepts.label: metasedimentary siliciclastic: pelite
concepts.definition: A group name for metamorphosed rocks derived from a fine-grained sedimentary siliciclastic protolith (usually with grain size below 0.0625 mm), i.e. the metamorphosed equivalent of a mudstone. Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 181) identify pelite as a restricted-use term, and define it as "... a term for a sedimentary rock composed of clay-sized particles. It has also been used locally for the metamorphosed equivalent of these sedimentary rocks, that is, a metamorphic rock with a high modal ratio of mica to quartz+feldspar. The SCMR recommends that it should be used only for sedimentary rocks and the term metapelite should be used for the metamorphosed equivalents." Acknowledging entrenched practises, GSWA usage departs from this recommendation, and allows the use of pelite as a noun for a metamorphosed equivalent of mudstone lithologies, as well as an adjective to qualify metamorphic rocks derived from these sedimentary types (e.g. pelitic schist).

concepts.label: metasomatic gneiss
concepts.definition: A metasomatic gneissose rock for which the protolith cannot be established. The timing of metasomatism is not implied and may precede or follow the development of gneissosity during regional metamorphism. A gneiss is a layered rock formed by regional metamorphism, in which bands or lenticles of granular minerals alternate with bands or lenticles in which minerals having flaky or elongate prismatic habits predominate (Fettes and Desmon, 2007, p. 154).

concepts.label: metasomatic granofels/hornfels
concepts.definition: A metasomatic rock composed of a mosaic of equidimensional grains without preferred orientation and for which the original protolith cannot be identified. Granofels are metamorphic rocks defined by their granofelsic structure, i.e. the absence of schistosity, such that the mineral grains and aggregates of mineral grains are equant or, if inequant, have random orientation. Mineralogical or lithological layering may be present. (Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 156); hornfels are granofels that formed as a result of contact metamorphism (Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 159).

concepts.label: metasomatic rock
concepts.definition: Metamorphic rock whose mineral and chemical bulk compositions have been substantially changed by metasomatism, i.e. the metamorphic process by which the chemical composition of a rock or rock portion is altered in a pervasive manner by the introduction and/or removal of chemical components as a result of interaction with aqueous fluids/solutions ((usually hydrothermal or static fluids); during metasomatism the rock remains in a solid state (Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 174).

concepts.label: metasomatic schist
concepts.definition: A metasomatic schistose rock for which the protolith cannot be established. The timing of metasomatism is not implied and may precede or follow the development of schistosity during regional metamorphism. A schist is a metamorphic rock displaying schistosity, i.e. a preferred orientation of inequant mineral grains or grain aggregates, such that the rock will split on a scale of less than a centimetre (well-developed schistosity), or on a scale of more than one centimetre (poorly-developed schistosity) (Fettes and Desmon, 2007, p. 193).

concepts.label: metasyenite
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed felsic intrusive rock derived from a syenite, i.e. an intrusive rock consisting mainly of alkali feldspar with subordinate sodic plagioclase, biotite, pyroxene, amphibole and occasional fayalite. Minor quartz or nepheline may also be present. Igneous protolith defined modally in QAPF field 7 (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 145).

concepts.label: metasyenogranite
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed felsic intrusive rock derived from a syenogranite, i.e. from a variety of granite in QAPF field 3a consisting of alkali feldspar with subordinate plagioclase (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 146).

concepts.label: metatonalite
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed felsic intrusive rock derived from a tonalite, i.e. an intrusive rock consisting essentially of quartz and intermediate plagioclase, usually with biotite and amphibole. Igneous protolith defined modally in QAPF field 5 (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 149).

concepts.label: metatrachyte
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed volcanic rock derived from a protolith consisting essentially of alkali feldspar. Igneous protolith defined modally in QAPF field 7 and, if modes are not available, chemically in TAS field T (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 151). GSWA's rock classification scheme prefers the use of volcanic terminology for any igneous rock formed on or near the Earth's surface, i.e. for those hypabyssal or subvolcanic rocks such as dykes, sills, and cryptodomes that are demonstrably both spatially and temporally associated with extrusive volcanic rocks.

concepts.label: metatroctolite
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed mafic intrusive rock (or coarse-grained parts of extrusive successions) derived from a troctolite, i.e. a variety of gabbro composed essentially of highly calcic plagioclase and olivine with little or no pyroxene. Igneous protolith defined modally in the gabbroic rock classification (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 151).

concepts.label: metavolcanic and metavolcaniclastic rock
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed rock derived from a volcanic or volcaniclastic protolith, but otherwise uncategorized in terms or composition or grain size.

concepts.label: meta-igneous volcanic or volcaniclastic
concepts.definition: A group name for metamorphosed lithologies derived from volcanic or volcaniclastic protoliths, but otherwise uncategorized in terms of composition or grain size.

concepts.label: micaceous fault rock
concepts.definition: A rock formed as a result of deformation in a fault zone and distinguished by the abundance of micaceous mineral phases. In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for fault rocks for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established.

concepts.label: micaceous gneiss
concepts.definition: A gneiss distinguished by the abundance of micaceous mineral phases. In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for a gneiss for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established. See also definition of gneiss/gneissose structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 154–155).

concepts.label: micaceous granofels/hornfels
concepts.definition: A granofels/hornfels distinguished by the abundance of micaceous mineral phases. In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for a granofels/hornfels for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established.

concepts.label: micaceous schist
concepts.definition: A schist distinguished by the abundance of micaceous mineral phases. In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for a schist for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established. See also definition of schist/schistose structure in Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p.  193).

concepts.label: micro alkali feldspar granite
concepts.definition: An alkali feldspar granite with a grain size of less than 3 mm. Includes porphyritic varieties.

concepts.label: micro alkali feldspar syenite
concepts.definition: An alkali feldspar syenite with a grain size of less than 3 mm. Includes porphyritic varieties.

concepts.label: micro granitic rock; undivided
concepts.definition: A granitic rock, undivided, with a grain size of less than 3 mm. Includes porphyritic varieties.

concepts.label: micro quartz alkali feldspar syenite
concepts.definition: A quartz alkali feldspar syenite with a grain size of less than 3 mm. Includes porphyritic varieties.

concepts.label: micro quartz anorthosite
concepts.definition: A quartz anorthosite with a grain size of less than 3 mm. Includes porphyritic varieties.

concepts.label: micro quartz diorite
concepts.definition: A quartz diorite with a grain size of less than 3 mm. Includes porphyritic varieties.

concepts.label: micro quartz gabbro
concepts.definition: A quartz gabbro with a grain size of less than 3 mm. Includes porphyritic varieties.

concepts.label: micro quartz monzodiorite
concepts.definition: A quartz monzodiorite with a grain size of less than 3 mm. Includes porphyritic varieties.

concepts.label: micro quartz monzogabbro
concepts.definition: A quartz monzogabbro with a grain size of less than 3 mm. Includes porphyritic varieties.

concepts.label: micro quartz monzonite
concepts.definition: A quartz monzonite with a grain size of less than 3 mm. Includes porphyritic varieties.

concepts.label: micro quartz syenite
concepts.definition: A quartz syenite with a grain size of less than 3 mm. Includes porphyritic varieties.

concepts.label: microbialitic dolomite
concepts.definition: A dolomitic rock distinguished by the presence of microbialites, i.e. 'organosedimentary deposits that have accreted as a result of a benthic microbial community trapping and binding detrital sediment and/or forming the locus of mineral precipitation' (Burne and Moore, 1987, p. 241–242). Note that past workers (including GSWA) commonly used the term ‘stromatolite’ to refer to all types of microbialite structures, whereas current usage restricts ‘stromatolite’ to those microbialites with a layered/laminated fabric (see Grey and Awramik 2020, p. 4); therefore, legacy usage of ‘stromatolitic dolomite’ or ‘stromatolitic dolostone’ is best considered equivalent to this lithology.

concepts.label: microbialitic limestone
concepts.definition: A limestone distinguished by the presence of microbialites, i.e. 'organosedimentary deposits that have accreted as a result of a benthic microbial community trapping and binding detrital sediment and/or forming the locus of mineral precipitation' (Burne and Moore, 1987, p. 241–242). Note that past workers (including GSWA) commonly used the term ‘stromatolite’ to refer to all types of microbialite structures, whereas current usage restricts ‘stromatolite’ to those microbialites with a layered/laminated fabric (see Grey and Awramik 2020, p. 4); therefore, legacy usage of ‘stromatolitic limestone’ is best considered equivalent to this lithology.

concepts.label: microbially laminated dolomite
concepts.definition: Laminated dolomite rock where the laminae have formed by the trapping of grains and precipitation of dolomite mud through the effects of eubacteria, cyanobacteria, and/or fungi in a microbial mat. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

concepts.label: microbially laminated limestone
concepts.definition: Laminated limestone where the laminae have formed by the trapping of grains and precipitation of calcite mud through the effects of eubacteria, cyanobacteria, and/or fungi in a microbial mat. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

concepts.label: microdiorite
concepts.definition: A diorite with a grain size of less than 3 mm. Includes porphyritic varieties.

concepts.label: microgranodiorite
concepts.definition: A granodiorite with a grain size of less than 3 mm. Includes porphyritic varieties.

concepts.label: micromonzodiorite
concepts.definition: A monzodiorite with a grain size of less than 3 mm. Includes porphyritic varieties.

concepts.label: micromonzogabbro
concepts.definition: A monzogabbro with a grain size of less than 3 mm. Includes porphyritic varieties.

concepts.label: micromonzogranite
concepts.definition: A monzogranite with a grain size of less than 3 mm. Includes porphyritic varieties.

concepts.label: micromonzonite
concepts.definition: A monzonite with a grain size of less than 3 mm. Includes porphyritic varieties.

concepts.label: microsyenite
concepts.definition: A syenite with a grain size of less than 3 mm. Includes porphyritic varieties.

concepts.label: microsyenogranite
concepts.definition: A syenogranite with a grain size of less than 3 mm. Includes porphyritic varieties.

concepts.label: microtonalite
concepts.definition: A tonalite with a grain size of less than 3 mm. Includes porphyritic varieties.

concepts.label: microtrondhjemite
concepts.definition: A trondhjemite with a grain size of less than 3 mm. Includes porphyritic varieties.

concepts.label: migmatitic fault rock
concepts.definition: A fault that developed in a migmatite, under migmatitic conditions. In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for fault rocks for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established.

concepts.label: migmatitic gneiss
concepts.definition: A metamorphic rock of uncertain protolith and characterized by the presence of both a gneissose structure and migmatitic components. The gneissic part retains a well-developed foliation, whereas the migmatite component includes bands or veins of leucosome within the granofelsic matrix. Adapted from https://geologyscience.com/rocks/metamorphic-rocks/foliated-metamorphic-rocks/migmatite/.

concepts.label: migmatitic granofels/hornfels
concepts.definition: A metamorphic rock of uncertain protolith and characterized by the presence of both a granofelsic structure and migmatitic components. The granofelsic part retains a well-developed foliation, whereas the migmatite component includes bands or veins of leucosome within the granofelsic matrix. Adapted from https://geologyscience.com/rocks/metamorphic-rocks/foliated-metamorphic-rocks/migmatite/.

concepts.label: migmatitic metacarbonatite
concepts.definition: Composite metamorphic rock derived from an igneous protolith containing a modal amount of primary carbonate minerals greater than 50% and pervasively heterogeneous on a meso- to megascopic scale. It typically consists of darker (melanosome) and lighter (leucosome) parts. The darker parts usually exhibit features of metamorphic rocks, whereas the lighter parts are of igneous appearance. See definition of migmatite in Fettes and Desmond (2007, p. 176).

concepts.label: migmatitic schist
concepts.definition: A metamorphic rock of uncertain protolith and characterized by the presence of both a schistose structure and migmatite portions. The schistose part exhibits a foliated texture, whereas the leucosome forms veins or layers within the schist. Adapted from https://geologyscience.com/rocks/metamorphic-rocks/foliated-metamorphic-rocks/migmatite/.

concepts.label: minette
concepts.definition: Originally an old miners’ term for oolitic ironstones. Later used for a variety of lamprophyre consisting of phenocrysts of phlogopite–biotite and occasionally amphiboles in a groundmass of the same minerals plus orthoclase and minor plagioclase. Mg-olivine and diopsidic pyroxene may also be present. Now defined in the lamprophyre classification (Table 2.9, p. 19). (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 112)

concepts.label: mixed carbonate/evaporite
concepts.definition: Carbonate and evaporite layers/beds interleaved at outcrop scale.

concepts.label: mixed chert and iron formation
concepts.definition: Iron formation and chert interleaved at meso- to megascopic scale.

concepts.label: mixed chert and mudstone
concepts.definition: Chert and mudstone layers/beds interleaved at outcrop scale.

concepts.label: mixed iron formation and mudstone
concepts.definition: Iron formation and mudstone interleaved at outcrop scale.

concepts.label: mixed limestone and dolomite
concepts.definition: Limestone and dolomite beds/layers/rocks interleaved at outcrop scale.

concepts.label: mixed lithology
concepts.definition: A prefix used in GSWA's Explanatory Notes system (ENS) to characterize interleaved lithologies that cannot be separated at the scale of mapping, with the first code representing the volumetrically most abundant lithology. Typically reserved for (a) lithologies that are tectonically interleaved, and (b) intrusive lithologies and their host. Interlayered lithologies in sedimentary successions are covered under sedimentary rock types, and the prefix 'j' is used specifically to describe lithologies hosting xenolith/inclusion.

concepts.label: mixed
concepts.definition: A prefix used in GSWA's Explanatory Notes system (ENS) to characterize the presence of more than one rock type.

concepts.label: mixed siliciclastic and volcanic rocks
concepts.definition: Siliciclastic rocks/beds/intervals and volcanic rocks/beds/intervals interleaved at outcrop scale.

concepts.label: monchiquite
concepts.definition: A variety of lamprophyre similar to camptonite except that the groundmass is feldspar-free and composed of combinations of glass and feldspathoids, especially analcime. Now defined in the lamprophyre classification (Table 2.9, p. 19). (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 113)

concepts.label: monomictic impact breccia
concepts.definition: Cataclasite produced by impact and displaying weak or no shock metamorphism. It occurs in the (par)autochthonous floor of an impact crater or (up to the size of blocks and megablocks) within allochthonous (polymictic) impact breccias (Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 177).

concepts.label: monzodiorite
concepts.definition: A term suggested to replace syenodiorite for an intrusive rock intermediate between monzonite and diorite. Now defined modally in QAPF field 9 (Fig. 2.4, p. 22). (cf. Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 113)

concepts.label: monzogabbro
concepts.definition: A term suggested to replace syenogabbro for an intrusive rock of gabbroic aspect that contains minor but essential orthoclase as well as calcic plagioclase. Now defined modally in QAPF field 9 (Fig. 2.4, p. 22). (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 113)

concepts.label: monzogranite
concepts.definition: An optional term for a variety of granite in QAPF field 3b (Fig. 2.4, p. 22) having roughly equal amounts of alkali feldspar and plagioclase (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 113)

concepts.label: monzonite
concepts.definition: An intrusive rock containing almost equal amounts of plagioclase and alkali feldspar with minor amphibole and/or pyroxene. Now defined modally in QAPF field 8 (Fig. 2.4, p. 22). Adapted from Le Maitre et al. (2005, p. 113).

concepts.label: mylonite
concepts.definition: Fault rock that is cohesive and characterized by a well-developed schistosity resulting from tectonic reduction of grain size for 50–90% of the rock volume, and commonly containing rounded porphyroclasts and lithic fragments of similar composition to minerals in the matrix. Fine-scale layering and an associated mineral or stretching lineation are commonly present. Brittle deformation of some minerals may be present, but deformation is commonly by crystal plasticity. Definition adapted from Fossen (2016) and Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 177).

concepts.label: mylonitized hydrothermal rock
concepts.definition: A hydrothermal rock characterized by a well-developed schistosity resulting from tectonic reduction of grain size (cf. definition of mylonite in Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 177).

concepts.label: mylonitized meta-igneous felsic rock
concepts.definition: A felsic igneous rock characterized by a well-developed schistosity resulting from tectonic reduction of grain size (cf. definition of mylonite in Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 177).

concepts.label: mylonitized meta-igneous mafic rock
concepts.definition: A mafic igneous rock characterized by a well-developed schistosity resulting from tectonic reduction of grain size (cf. definition of mylonite in Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 177).

concepts.label: mylonitized meta-iron formation
concepts.definition: An iron formation characterized by a well-developed schistosity resulting from tectonic reduction of grain size (cf. definition of mylonite in Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 177).

concepts.label: mylonitized meta-ultramafic intrusive rock
concepts.definition: An ultramafic igneous (intrusive or coarse-grained extrusive) rock characterized by a well-developed schistosity resulting from tectonic reduction of grain size (cf. definition of mylonite in Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 177).

concepts.label: mylonitized meta-ultramafic rock; volcanic or undivided
concepts.definition: An ultramafic volcanic or volcaniclastic rock characterized by a well-developed schistosity resulting from tectonic reduction of grain size (cf. definition of mylonite in Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 177).

concepts.label: mylonitized metacarbonate rock
concepts.definition: A carbonate-rich rock characterized by a well-developed schistosity resulting from tectonic reduction of grain size (cf. definition of mylonite in Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 177).

concepts.label: mylonitized metacarbonatite
concepts.definition: A carbonatite characterized by a well-developed schistosity resulting from tectonic reduction of grain size (cf. definition of mylonite in Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 177)

concepts.label: mylonitized metachert
concepts.definition: A chert rock characterized by a well-developed schistosity resulting from tectonic reduction of grain size (cf. definition of mylonite in Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 177).

concepts.label: mylonitized metaconglomerate
concepts.definition: A siliciclastic rock originally consisting of particles greater than sand size (i.e. a conglomerate) that is characterized by a well-developed schistosity resulting from tectonic reduction of grain size (cf. definition of mylonite in Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 177).

concepts.label: mylonitized metafelsic volcanic rock
concepts.definition: A felsic volcanic rock characterized by a well-developed schistosity resulting from tectonic reduction of grain size (cf. definition of mylonite in Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 177). GSWA's rock classification scheme prefers the use of volcanic terminology for any igneous rock formed on or near the Earth's surface, i.e. for those hypabyssal or subvolcanic rocks such as dykes, sills, and cryptodomes that are demonstrably both spatially and temporally associated with extrusive volcanic rocks.

concepts.label: mylonitized metagranitic rock
concepts.definition: A felsic intrusive rock characterized by a well-developed schistosity resulting from tectonic reduction of grain size (cf. definition of mylonite in Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 177).

concepts.label: mylonitized metamafic intrusive rock
concepts.definition: A mafic intrusive rock (or coarse-grained parts of extrusive successions) characterized by a well-developed schistosity resulting from tectonic reduction of grain size (cf. definition of mylonite in Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 177).

concepts.label: mylonitized metamafic volcanic rock
concepts.definition: A mafic volcanic rock characterized by a well-developed schistosity resulting from tectonic reduction of grain size (cf. definition of mylonite in Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 177). GSWA's rock classification scheme prefers the use of volcanic terminology for any igneous rock formed on or near the Earth's surface, i.e. for those hypabyssal or subvolcanic rocks such as dykes, sills, and cryptodomes that are demonstrably both spatially and temporally associated with extrusive volcanic rocks.

concepts.label: mylonitized metasandstone
concepts.definition: A siliciclastic rock originally consisting of sand-sized particles that is characterized by a well-developed schistosity resulting from tectonic reduction of grain size (cf. definition of mylonite in Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 177).

concepts.label: mylonitized metasiliciclastic rock
concepts.definition: A siliciclastic rock characterized by a well-developed schistosity resulting from tectonic reduction of grain size (cf. definition of mylonite in Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 177).

concepts.label: mylonitized metasomatic rock
concepts.definition: A metasomatic rock that has experienced deformation by extreme microbrecciation.

concepts.label: mylonitized metavolcanic or metavolcaniclastic rock
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed volcanic or volcaniclastic rock otherwise uncategorized that is characterized by a well-developed schistosity resulting from tectonic reduction of grain size (cf. definition of mylonite in Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 177).

concepts.label: mylonitized pelite
concepts.definition: A fine-grained siliciclastic rock characterized by a well-developed schistosity resulting from tectonic reduction of grain size (cf. definition of mylonite in Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 177).

concepts.label: mylonitized psammite and pelite
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed sequence of rocks originally consisting of interleaved sandstone and mudstone beds that is characterized by a well-developed schistosity resulting from tectonic reduction of grain size (cf. definition of mylonite in Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 177).

concepts.label: metasedimentary siliciclastic: psammite and pelite; interlayered
concepts.definition: A group name for metamorphosed rocks derived from a succession of interleaved sandstone and mudstone beds, i.e. sedimentary siliciclastic protoliths with grain size between 0.0625 and 2 mm and less than 0.0625 mm respectively. Acknowledging entrenched practises, GSWA usage allows the use of psammite and pelite as nouns for metamorphosed equivalent of sandstone and mudstone lithologies, as well as adjectives to qualify metamorphic rocks derived from these sedimentary types.

concepts.label: mylonitized semipelite
concepts.definition: A fine-grained siliciclastic rock characterized by a well-developed schistosity resulting from tectonic reduction of grain size (cf. definition of mylonite in Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 177), and with a modal ratio of mica to quartz + feldspar intermediate between a pelite and a psammite.

concepts.label: metasedimentary siliciclastic: semipelite
concepts.definition: A group name for metamorphosed rocks with a modal ratio of mica to quartz + feldspar intermediate between a pelite and a psammite, a crystalloblastic nature, and derived from a fine- to medium-grained siliciclastic sedimentary protolith.

concepts.label: norite
concepts.definition: An intrusive rock composed essentially of bytownite, labradorite or andesine and orthopyroxene. Now defined modally in the gabbroic rock classification (Fig. 2.6, p. 25). (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 117)

concepts.label: olivine-clinopyroxene norite
concepts.definition: An intrusive rock defined modally in the gabbroic rock classification (Fig. 2.6, p. 25) as a variety of norite in which olivine is between 5% and 85% and clinopyroxene exceeds 5% of the pyroxenes. (cf. Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 120)

concepts.label: olivine clinopyroxenite
concepts.definition: An ultramafic intrusive rock consisting essentially of clinopyroxene and 10–40% olivine. Now defined modally in the ultramafic rock classification (Fig. 2.9, p. 28). Adapted from Le Maitre et al. (2005, p. 119).

concepts.label: olivine-diopside-richterite madupitic lamproite
concepts.definition: Originally described as a variety of olivine phonolitic leucitite composed essentially of leucite and diopside, and with subordinate olivine, alkali feldspar and phlogopite. Now regarded as an olivine–diopside–richterite madupitic lamproite (Table 2.7, p. 17), with the term 'madupitic' referring to the presence of poikilitic groundmass phlogopite. The original name jumillite is not recommended for usage. (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 94)

concepts.label: olivine gabbro
concepts.definition: A commonly used name for a gabbro containing essential olivine. Now defined modally in the gabbroic rock classification (Fig. 2.6, p. 25) as a variety of gabbro in which olivine is between 5% and 85%. (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 119)

concepts.label: olivine gabbronorite
concepts.definition: A collective term for intrusive rocks consisting of 10–90% calcic plagioclase and accompanied by olivine, orthopyroxene and clinopyroxene in various amounts. Now defined modally in the gabbroic rock classification (Fig. 2.6, p. 25) as a variety of gabbronorite in which olivine is between 5% and 85%. (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 119)

concepts.label: olivine-hornblende pyroxenite
concepts.definition: An ultramafic intrusive rock consisting of more than 30% pyroxene accompanied by hornblende and olivine in various amounts. Now defined modally in the ultramafic rock classification (Fig. 2.9, p. 28). (cf. Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 119)

concepts.label: olivine hornblendite
concepts.definition: An ultramafic intrusive rock consisting essentially of amphibole and up to 40% olivine. Now defined modally in the ultramafic rock classification (Fig. 2.9, p. 28). Adapted from Le Maitre et al. (2005, p. 119).

concepts.label: olivine melilitolite
concepts.definition: An ultramafic intrusive rock containing at least 10% melilite, at least 10% olivine, and less than 10% clinopyroxene (Glossary of geology, Neuendorf et al., 2011, 5th edition, revised). Note that in Le Maitre et al.'s glossary (2005, p. 120), olivine melilitolite is described as "originally defined as an ultramafic plutonic rock consisting essentially of melilite and olivine with minor clinopyroxene (see 1st Edition, Fig. B.3, p. 12), but not required by the new melilite-bearing rocks classification (section 2.4.1, p. 11)".

concepts.label: olivine norite
concepts.definition: An old term for a norite containing essential olivine. Now defined modally in the gabbroic rock classification (Fig. 2.6, p. 25) as a variety of norite in which olivine is between 5% and 85%. (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 120)

concepts.label: olivine-orthopyroxene gabbro
concepts.definition: An intrusive rock defined modally in the gabbroic rock classification (Fig. 2.6, p. 25) as a variety of gabbro in which olivine is between 5% and 85% and orthopyroxene exceeds 5% of the pyroxenes. (cf. olivine gabbro/gabbronorite in Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 119)

concepts.label: olivine orthopyroxenite
concepts.definition: An ultramafic intrusive rock consisting essentially of orthopyroxene and 10–40% olivine. Now defined modally in the ultramafic rock classification (Fig. 2.9, p. 28). Adapted from Le Maitre et al. (2005, p. 120).

concepts.label: olivine-pyroxene hornblendite
concepts.definition: An ultramafic intrusive rock consisting of more than 30% amphibole accompanied by pyroxene and olivine in various amounts. Now defined modally in the ultramafic rock classification (Fig. 2.9, p. 28). (cf. Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 120)

concepts.label: olivine-pyroxene kalsilitite
concepts.definition: An ultrabasic rock consisting of phenocrysts of olivine and minor pyroxene in a groundmass of diopside and kalsilite with small amounts of perovskite, olivine and biotite. The historical term mafurite is considered obsolete. Cf. Tables 2.5 & 2.6 on p. 12, and p. 107 in Le Maitre et al. (2005).

concepts.label: olivine-pyroxene melilitolite
concepts.definition: In the IUGS classification (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 11), an intrusive rock consisting mostly of melilite, olivine, and clinopyroxene, with clinopyroxene > olivine (Glossary of geology, Neuendorf et al., 2011, 5th edition, revised)).

concepts.label: olivine pyroxenite
concepts.definition: An ultramafic intrusive rock consisting essentially of pyroxene and 10–40% olivine. Now defined modally in the ultramafic rock classification (Fig. 2.9, p. 28). Adapted from Le Maitre et al. (2005, p. 120).

concepts.label: olivine websterite
concepts.definition: An ultramafic intrusive rock consisting of 10–40% olivine with various amounts of clinopyroxene and orthopyroxene. Now defined modally in the ultramafic rock classification (Fig. 2.9, p. 28). (cf. Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 120)

concepts.label: oolitic/peloidal dolomite
concepts.definition: A dolomite rock characterized by the presence of ooliths and/or peloids. Ooliths are small round or ovate accretionary bodies resembling the roe of fish, with a diameter of 0.25 to 2 mm (commonly 0.5 to 1 mm), and usually formed of calcium carbonate (but also dolomite, silica, or other minerals) in successive concentric layers, commonly around a nucleus such as a shell fragment, an algal pellet, or a quartz-sand grain, in shallow, wave-agitated water; ooliths commonly show an internal radiating fibrous structure indicating outward growth or enlargement at the site of deposition, and are frequently formed by inorganic precipitation. Peloids are allochems composed of micrite, irrespective of size or origin, for which an exact origin is unknown (e.g. completely micritized fossils or ooids); other types of peloid include pseudo-ooids and aggregates produced by gas bubbling, by microbial precipitation, or by other intraformational reworking of lithified or semilithified carbonate mud. Adapted from Glossary of geology (2011, 5th edition revised).

concepts.label: oolitic/peloidal limestone
concepts.definition: A limestone characterized by the presence of ooliths and/or peloids. Ooliths are small round or ovate accretionary bodies resembling the roe of fish, with a diameter of 0.25 to 2 mm (commonly 0.5 to 1 mm), and usually formed of calcium carbonate (but also dolomite, silica, or other minerals) in successive concentric layers, commonly around a nucleus such as a shell fragment, an algal pellet, or a quartz-sand grain, in shallow, wave-agitated water; ooliths commonly show an internal radiating fibrous structure indicating outward growth or enlargement at the site of deposition, and are frequently formed by inorganic precipitation. Peloids are allochems composed of micrite, irrespective of size or origin, for which an exact origin is unknown (e.g. completely micritized fossils or ooids); other types of peloid include pseudo-ooids and aggregates produced by gas bubbling, by microbial precipitation, or by other intraformational reworking of lithified or semilithified carbonate mud. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

concepts.label: orthopyroxene gabbro
concepts.definition: A basic intrusive rock consisting mainly of calcic plagioclase, clinopyroxene and minor orthopyroxene. Now defined modally in the gabbroic rock classification (Fig. 2.6, p. 25). (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 122)

concepts.label: orthopyroxenite
concepts.definition: An ultramafic intrusive rock consisting almost entirely of orthopyroxene. Now defined modally in the ultramafic rock classification (Fig. 2.9, p. 28). (cf. Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 122)

concepts.label: peat
concepts.definition: An unconsolidated deposit of semi-carbonized plant remains in a water-saturated environment, such as a bog or fen, and of persistently high moisture content (at least 75%). It is an early stage or rank in the development of coal; carbon content is about 60% and oxygen content is about 30% (moisture-free). Structures of the vegetal matter may or may not be seen depending on the degree of organic matter degradation. When dried, peat burns freely. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

concepts.label: pebble conglomerate
concepts.definition: A consolidated rock consisting mainly of pebbles (2–64 mm or -1 to -4 phi units) being somewhat rounded or otherwise modified by abrasion in the course of transport. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

concepts.label: pebbly sandstone
concepts.definition: A consolidated pebbly sand containing 10–20% pebbles in a matrix-supported framework. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

concepts.label: pegmatite
concepts.definition: An exceptionally coarse-grained igneous rock, with interlocking crystals, usually found as irregular dykes, lenses, or veins, especially at the margins of batholiths. Most grains are 1 cm or more in diameter. Although pegmatites having gross compositions similar to other rock types are known, their composition is generally that of granite; the composition may be simple or complex and may include rare minerals rich in such elements as lithium, boron, fluorine, niobium, tantalum, uranium, and rare earths. Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (Neuendorf et al., 2011, 5th edition, revised).

concepts.label: pelitic gneiss
concepts.definition: Type of gneiss derived by metamorphism of an aluminium-rich, fine-grained sedimentary or metasedimentary protolith. See also definition of gneiss/gneissose structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 154–155).

concepts.label: pelitic granofels/hornfels
concepts.definition: Type of granofels/hornfels derived by (contact) metamorphism of an aluminium-rich, argillaceous or fine-grained sedimentary or metasedimentary protolith. Adapted from Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 182). See also definition of granofels/granofelsic structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 156); hornfels are granofels formed by contact metamorphism (Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 159).

concepts.label: pelitic migmatite
concepts.definition: Composite silicate metamorphic rock derived from a fine-grained siliciclastic sedimentary or metasedimentary protolith, pervasively heterogeneous on a meso- to megascopic scale. It typically consists of darker (melanosome) and lighter (leucosome) parts. The darker parts usually exhibit features of metamorphic rocks, whereas the lighter parts are of igneous appearance. See definition of migmatite in Fettes and Desmond (2007, p. 176).

concepts.label: pelitic schist
concepts.definition: Type of schist derived by metamorphism of an aluminium-rich, fine-grained sedimentary or metasedimentary protolith. See also definition of schist/schistose structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 193).

concepts.label: peridotite
concepts.definition: A collective term for ultramafic rocks consisting essentially of olivine with pyroxene and/or amphibole. Now defined modally in the ultramafic rock classification (Fig. 2.9, p. 28). (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 126)

concepts.label: phosphorite
concepts.definition: A sedimentary rock with a high enough content of phosphate minerals to be of economic interest. Most commonly it is a bedded primary or reworked secondary marine rock composed of microcrystalline carbonate fluorapatite in the form of laminae, pellets, oolites, nodules, and skeletal, shell, and bone fragments. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

concepts.label: phyllite
concepts.definition: Fine- to medium-grained metamorphic rock characterized by a lustrous sheen and a well-developed schistosity resulting from the parallel arrangement of phyllosilicates. Phyllite is usually of low metamorphic grade. Originally introduced as an alternative to 'phyllade' (term now superseded) to describe a fine-grained schist composed predominantly of micaceous minerals, and as such forming a transition between a (clay-)slate and a mica schist. (Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 183)

concepts.label: phyllonite
concepts.definition: Phyllosilicate-rich mylonite that has the lustrous sheen of a phyllite (Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 183).

concepts.label: pisolite
concepts.definition: A sedimentary rock made up chiefly of pisoids cemented together. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

concepts.label: protocataclasite
concepts.definition: A cohesive fault rock with a poorly developed or absent schistosity, characterized by generally angular porphyroclasts and lithic fragments in a finer-grained matrix of similar composition that constitutes between 10 and 50% of the rock volume. Definition adapted from Fossen (2016) and Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 188).

concepts.label: protomylonite
concepts.definition: A mylonite in which less than 50% of the rock volume has undergone grain-size reduction (Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 188); a mylonite with 10–50% matrix and 50–90% porphyroclasts (Passchier and Trouw, 2005).

concepts.label: psammite and pelite; interlayered
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed sequence of rocks derived from a interleaving of sandstone and mudstone, i.e. siliciclastic sedimentary protoliths with grain size between 0.0625 and 2 mm and less than 0.0625 mm respectively.

concepts.label: psammitic and pelitic gneiss; interlayered
concepts.definition: A gneissose sequence derived by metamorphism of a sedimentary or metasedimentary succession largely consisting of interleaved sandstone and mudstone beds. See also definition of gneiss/gneissose structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 154–155).

concepts.label: psammitic and pelitic granofels/hornfels; interlayered
concepts.definition: A granofels/hornfels derived by (contact) metamorphism of a sedimentary or metasedimentary succession largely consisting of interleaved sandstone and mudstone beds. See also definition of granofels/granofelsic structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 156); hornfels are granofels formed by contact metamorphism (Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 159).

concepts.label: psammitic and pelitic migmatite; interlayered
concepts.definition: Composite silicate metamorphic rock derived from a siliciclastic sedimentary or metasedimentary succession consisting of interleaved sandstone and mudstone beds, and pervasively heterogeneous on a meso- to megascopic scale. It typically consists of darker (melanosome) and lighter (leucosome) parts. The darker parts usually exhibit features of metamorphic rocks, whereas the lighter parts are of igneous appearance. See definition of migmatite in Fettes and Desmond (2007, p. 176).

concepts.label: psammitic and pelitic schist; interlayered
concepts.definition: A schistose sequence derived by metamorphism of a sedimentary or metasedimentary succession largely consisting of interleaved sandstone and mudstone beds. See also definition of schist/schistose structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 193).

concepts.label: psammitic gneiss
concepts.definition: Type of gneiss derived by metamorphism of a sedimentary or metasedimentary protolith largely consisting of sand-size particles. See also definition of gneiss/gneissose structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 154–155).

concepts.label: psammitic granofels/hornfels
concepts.definition: Type of granofels/hornfels derived by (contact) metamorphism of a sedimentary or metasedimentary protolith largely consisting of sand-size particles. See also definition of granofels/granofelsic structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 156); hornfels are granofels formed by contact metamorphism (Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 159).

concepts.label: psammitic migmatite
concepts.definition: Composite silicate metamorphic rock derived from a siliciclastic sedimentary or metasedimentary protolith largely consisting of sand-size particles. Pervasively heterogeneous on a meso- to megascopic scale, it typically consists of darker (melanosome) and lighter (leucosome) parts. The darker parts usually exhibit features of metamorphic rocks, whereas the lighter parts are of igneous appearance. See definition of migmatite in Fettes and Desmond (2007, p. 176).

concepts.label: psammitic schist
concepts.definition: Type of schist derived by metamorphism of a sedimentary or metasedimentary protolith largely consisting of sand-size particles. See also definition of schist/schistose structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 193).

concepts.label: psephitic gneiss
concepts.definition: Type of gneiss derived by metamorphism of a sedimentary or metasedimentary protolith largely consisting of conglomerate. See also definition of gneiss/gneissose structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 154–155).

concepts.label: psephitic granofels/hornfels
concepts.definition: Type of granofels/hornfels derived by (contact) metamorphism of a sedimentary or metasedimentary protolith largely consisting of particles larger than sand size. See also definition of granofels/granofelsic structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 156); hornfels are granofels formed by contact metamorphism (Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 159).

concepts.label: psephitic schist
concepts.definition: Type of schist derived by metamorphism of a sedimentary or metasedimentary protolith largely consisting largely of conglomerate. See also definition of schist/schistose structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 193).

concepts.label: pseudotachylite (fault rock)
concepts.definition: Extremely fine-grained to glassy, dark, cohesive rock occurring as veins or as a matrix to pseudo-conglomerates or breccias, formed through frictional melting and subsequent quenching during earthquakes and large-scale landslides (Trouw et al., 2010). Note the vocabulary has a separate concept for pseudotachylite formed through impact events.

concepts.label: pseudotachylite (impactite)
concepts.definition: Pseudotachylite produced by impact metamorphism. Dyke-like breccia formed by frictional melting in the basement of impact craters, resulting often in irregular vein-like networks. Typically, it contains unshocked and shocked mineral and lithic clasts in a fine-grained aphanitic matrix. (Cf. Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 162)

concepts.label: pyroxene-hornblende gabbro
concepts.definition: An intrusive rock (and including coarse-grained parts of extrusive successions) defined modally in the gabbroic rock classification (Fig. 2.6, p. 25) as a variety of gabbro in which hornblende is between 5% and 85% (cf. Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 133).

concepts.label: pyroxene-hornblende gabbronorite
concepts.definition: An intrusive rock (and including coarse-grained parts of extrusive successions) defined modally in the gabbroic rock classification (Fig. 2.6, p. 25) as a variety of gabbronorite in which hornblende is between 5% and 85% (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 133).

concepts.label: pyroxene-hornblende norite
concepts.definition: An intrusive rock (and including coarse-grained parts of extrusive successions) defined modally in the gabbroic rock classification (Fig. 2.6, p. 25) as a variety of norite in which hornblende is between 5% and 85% (cf. Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 133).

concepts.label: pyroxene-hornblende peridotite
concepts.definition: An ultramafic intrusive rock consisting of 40–90% olivine and various amounts of pyroxene and amphibole. Now defined modally in the ultramafic rock classification (Fig. 2.9, p. 28). (cf. Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 133)

concepts.label: pyroxene hornblendite
concepts.definition: A term for ultramafic intrusive rocks composed mainly of amphibole with up to 50% pyroxene. Now defined modally in the ultramafic rock classification (Fig. 2.9, p. 28). (cf. Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 133)

concepts.label: pyroxene melilitolite
concepts.definition: In the IUGS classification (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 11), an ultramafic intrusive rock consisting mostly of melilite and clinopyroxene, with less than 10% olivine (adapted from Glossary of geology, Neuendorf et al., 2011, 5th edition, revised). Note that in Le Maitre et al.'s glossary (2005, p. 133), pyroxene olivine melilitolite is described as "originally defined as an ultramafic plutonic rock consisting essentially of melilite and clinopyroxene with minor olivine (see 1st Edition, Fig. B.3, p. 12), but not required by the new melilite-bearing rocks classification (section 2.4.1, p. 11)."

concepts.label: pyroxene-olivine melilitolite
concepts.definition: In the IUGS classification (Le Maitre et al., p. 11), an ultramafic intrusive rock consisting mostly of melilite, olivine, and clinopyroxene, with olivine>clinopyroxene (adapted from Glossary of geology, Neuendorf et al., 2011, 5th edition, revised). Note that in Le Maitre et al.'s glossary (2005, p. 133), pyroxene olivine melilitolite is described as "originally defined as an ultramafic plutonic rock consisting essentially of melilite, olivine and lesser amounts of clinopyroxene (see 1st Edition, Fig. B.3, p. 12), but not required by the new melilite-bearing rocks classification (section 2.4.1, p. 11)".

concepts.label: pyroxene peridotite
concepts.definition: A term for intrusive rocks composed mainly of olivine with 10–60% pyroxene. Now defined modally in the ultramafic rock classification (Fig. 2.9, p. 28). Adapted from Le Maitre et al. (2005, p. 134).

concepts.label: pyroxene spinifex-textured basalt
concepts.definition: A volcanic basaltic rock distinguished by the presence of pyroxene spinifex texture, i.e. an igneous texture consisting of needle-like pyroxene crystals usually forming a criss-crossing pattern, the result of rapid quenching from unusually high temperatures (cf. https://glossary.americangeosciences.org/term/spinifextexture). Note that the term is commonly used as a proxy for high-magnesium basaltic rocks but in GSWA usage it is not synonymous with komatiitic basalt. The GSWA's rock classification scheme prefers the use of volcanic terminology for any igneous rock formed on or near the Earth's surface, i.e. for those hypabyssal or subvolcanic rocks such as dykes, sills, and cryptodomes that are demonstrably both spatially and temporally associated with extrusive volcanic rocks.

concepts.label: pyroxenite (extrusive)
concepts.definition: An ultramafic igneous rock composed almost entirely of one or more pyroxenes and occasionally biotite, hornblende and olivine. Now defined modally in the ultramafic rock classification (Fig. 2.9, p. 28). Definition adapted from Le Maitre et al. (2005, p. 134). In GSWA usage an 'extrusive' pyroxenite is identified as one formed from fractionation within thick bodies of ultramafic volcanic or subvolcanic magmas. GSWA's rock classification scheme prefers the use of volcanic terminology for any igneous rock formed on or near the Earth's surface, i.e. for those hypabyssal or subvolcanic rocks such as dykes, sills, and cryptodomes that are demonstrably both spatially and temporally associated with extrusive volcanic rocks.

concepts.label: pyroxenite (intrusive)
concepts.definition: An ultramafic intrusive rocks composed almost entirely of one or more pyroxenes and occasionally biotite, hornblende and olivine. Now defined modally in the ultramafic rock classification (Fig. 2.9, p. 28). Adapted from Le Maitre et al. (2005, p. 134).

concepts.label: pyroxenitic fault rock
concepts.definition: A rock formed as a result of deformation in a fault zone and distinguished by the abundance of pyroxenes. In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for fault rocks for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established.

concepts.label: pyroxenitic gneiss
concepts.definition: A gneiss distinguished by the abundance of pyroxenes. In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for gneiss for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established. See also definition of gneiss/gneissose structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 154–155).

concepts.label: pyroxenitic granofels/hornfels
concepts.definition: A granofels/hornfels distinguished by the abundance of pyroxenes. In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for a granofels/hornfels for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established.

concepts.label: pyroxenitic schist
concepts.definition: A schist distinguished by the abundance of pyroxenes. In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for a schist for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established. See also definition of schist/schistose structure in Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 193).

concepts.label: quartz alkali feldspar syenite
