concepts.definition: A felsic intrusive rock composed mainly of alkali feldspar, quartz and mafic minerals. Now defined modally in QAPF field 6* (Fig. 2.4, p. 22). (cf. Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 134)

concepts.label: quartz anorthosite
concepts.definition: A leucocratic intrusive rock consisting essentially of calcic plagioclase, quartz and with small amounts of pyroxene. Now defined modally in QAPF field 10* (Fig. 2.4, p. 22). The term is synonymous with plagioclasite. (cf. Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 134)

concepts.label: quartz diorite
concepts.definition: An intrusive rock having the composition of diorite but with an appreciable amount of quartz, i.e. between 5 and 20% of the felsic minerals, and defined modally in QAPF field 10* (Fig. 2.4, p. 22). Adapted from Le Maitre et al. (2005, p. 134).

concepts.label: quartz gabbro
concepts.definition: An intrusive rock composed mainly of calcic plagioclase, clinopyroxene and quartz. Now defined modally in QAPF field 10* (Fig. 2.4, p. 22). (cf. Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 134)

concepts.label: quartz latite
concepts.definition: A term originally used for a volcanic rock composed of phenocrysts of quartz, plagioclase, biotite and hornblende in a glassy matrix potentially of quartz and alkali feldspar. Now commonly used for volcanic rocks composed of alkali feldspar and plagioclase in roughly equal amounts, quartz and mafic minerals. Now defined modally in QAPF field 8* (Fig. 2.4, p. 22). Definition from Le Maitre et al. (2005, p. 135). GSWA's rock classification scheme prefers the use of volcanic terminology for any igneous rock formed on or near the Earth's surface, i.e. for those hypabyssal or subvolcanic rocks such as dykes, sills, and cryptodomes that are demonstrably both spatially and temporally associated with extrusive volcanic rocks.

concepts.label: quartz-mica schist
concepts.definition: A schist distinguished by the abundance of quartz and micaceous mineral phases. In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for a schist for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established. See also definition of schist/schistose structure in Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 193).

concepts.label: quartz monzodiorite
concepts.definition: An intrusive rock consisting essentially of sodic plagioclase, alkali feldspar, quartz and mafic minerals. Now defined modally in QAPF field 9* (Fig. 2.4, p. 22). (cf. Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 135).

concepts.label: quartz monzogabbro
concepts.definition: An intrusive rock consisting essentially of calcic plagioclase, alkali feldspar, quartz and mafic minerals. Now defined modally in QAPF field 9* (Fig. 2.4, p. 22). (cf. Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 135).

concepts.label: quartz monzonite
concepts.definition: An intrusive rock consisting of approximately equal amounts of alkali feldspar and plagioclase and with essential quartz (5–20% of felsic minerals) but not enough to make the rock a granite. Now defined modally in QAPF field 8* (Fig. 2.4, p. 22). (cf. Le Maitre et al., 2005, p.  135)

concepts.label: quartz syenite
concepts.definition: An intrusive rock consisting essentially of alkali feldspar, quartz and mafic minerals. Now defined modally in QAPF field 7* (Fig. 2.4, p. 22). (cf. Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 135)

concepts.label: quartz trachyte
concepts.definition: A volcanic rock consisting of phenocrysts of alkali feldspar and quartz in a cryptocrystalline or glassy matrix. It is the volcanic equivalent of quartz syenite. Now defined modally in QAPF field 7* (Fig. 2.11, p. 31). Definition from Le Maitre et al. (2005, p. 135). GSWA's rock classification scheme prefers the use of volcanic terminology for any igneous rock formed on or near the Earth's surface, i.e. for those hypabyssal or subvolcanic rocks such as dykes, sills, and cryptodomes that are demonstrably both spatially and temporally associated with extrusive volcanic rocks.

concepts.label: quartz vein
concepts.definition: A rock comprising quartz crystals of hydrothermal origin, as vein-filling material.

concepts.label: quartz wacke
concepts.definition: A wacke that contains more than 90% quartz and less than 5% each of feldspar and rock/lithic grains. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

concepts.label: quartzarenite
concepts.definition: An arenite composed primarily of quartz (excluding detrital chert grains); specifically one containing more than 95% quartz framework grains and less than 5% feldspar and rock/lithic grains. The term is essentially equivalent to orthoquartzite, which in some past GSWA usage has been abbreviated to quartzite. GSWA reserves the use of 'quartzite' for a demonstrably metamorphosed rock. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

concepts.label: quartzite
concepts.definition: A granoblastic metamorphic rock consisting mainly of quartz and formed by recrystallization of sandstone or chert by either regional or thermal metamorphism (Glossary of geology, 5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011). Note that GSWA usage restricts the use of the term quartzite to metamorphic rocks.

concepts.label: quartzofeldspathic fault rock
concepts.definition: A rock formed as a result of deformation in a fault zone and distinguished by the abundance of quartz and feldspar mineral phases. In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for fault rocks for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established.

concepts.label: quartzofeldspathic gneiss
concepts.definition: A gneiss distinguished by the abundance of quartz and feldspar mineral phases. In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for a gneiss for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established. See also definition of gneiss/gneissose structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 154–155).

concepts.label: quartzofeldspathic granofels/hornfels
concepts.definition: A granofels/hornfels distinguished by the abundance of quartz and feldspar mineral phases. In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for a granofels/hornfels for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established.

concepts.label: quartzofeldspathic schist
concepts.definition: A schist distinguished by the abundance of quartz and feldspar mineral phases. In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for a schist for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established. See also definition of schist/schistose structure in Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 193).

concepts.label: quartzose fault rock
concepts.definition: A rock formed as a result of deformation in a fault zone and distinguished by the abundance of quartz. In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for fault rocks for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established.

concepts.label: quartzose gneiss
concepts.definition: A gneiss distinguished by the abundance of quartz. In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for a gneiss for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established. See also definition of gneiss/gneissose structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 154–155).

concepts.label: quartzose hornfels
concepts.definition: Term proposed to distinguish a quartzite formed by contact metamorphism from other types of metamorphic quartzite. (Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 190)

concepts.label: quartzose schist
concepts.definition: A schist distinguished by the abundance of quartz. In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for a schist for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established. See also definition of schist/schistose structure in Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 193).

concepts.label: radiolarite
concepts.definition: The comparatively hard, fine-grained, chert-like, homogeneous consolidated equivalent of radiolarian earth; indurated radiolarian ooze. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

concepts.label: reaction skarn
concepts.definition: A skarn formed by local exchange of material by diffusion and reaction across contacts between carbonate beds and silicate sedimentary or other suitable (chemically different) rock types.

concepts.label: rhyodacite
concepts.definition: A term used for volcanic rocks intermediate between rhyolite and dacite, usually consisting of phenocrysts of quartz, plagioclase and a few ferromagnesian minerals in a microcrystalline groundmass. Definition from Le Maitre et al. (2005, p. 137). GSWA's rock classification scheme prefers the use of volcanic terminology for any igneous rock formed on or near the Earth's surface, i.e. for those hypabyssal or subvolcanic rocks such as dykes, sills, and cryptodomes that are demonstrably both spatially and temporally associated with extrusive volcanic rocks.

concepts.label: rhyolite
concepts.definition: A collective term for silicic volcanic rocks consisting of phenocrysts of quartz and alkali feldspar, often with minor plagioclase and biotite, in a microcrystalline or glassy groundmass and having the chemical composition of granite. Now defined modally in QAPF field 3 (Fig. 2.11, p. 31) and, if modes are not available, chemically in TAS field R (Fig. 2.14, p. 35). Definition from Le Maitre et al. (2005, p. 137). GSWA's rock classification scheme prefers the use of volcanic terminology for any igneous rock formed on or near the Earth's surface, i.e. for those hypabyssal or subvolcanic rocks such as dykes, sills, and cryptodomes that are demonstrably both spatially and temporally associated with extrusive volcanic rocks.

concepts.label: rodingite
concepts.definition: Metasomatic rock primarily composed of grossular–andradite garnet and calcic pyroxene; epidote, scapolite and iron ore are characteristic accessories. Rodingite mostly replaces dykes or inclusions of basic rocks within serpentinized ultramafic bodies, such as volcanic rocks or amphibolites associated with ultramafic bodies. (Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 191)

concepts.label: sand
concepts.definition: A weekly cemented aggregate of mineral or rock particles of sand size, having a diameter in the range of 0.0625 to 2 mm (62–2000 μm, or 4 to -1 phi units). The material is most commonly composed of quartz resulting from rock disintegration, and when the term 'sand' is used without qualification, a siliceous composition is implied; but the particles may be of any mineral composition or mixture of rock or mineral fragments, such as 'coral sand' consisting of limestone fragments. Also, a mass of such material, especially on a beach, a desert or in a stream bed. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

concepts.label: sandstone + conglomerate
concepts.definition: Sandstone and conglomerate beds/intervals interleaved at outcrop scale.

concepts.label: sandstone + other siliciclastic rock
concepts.definition: Dominant sandstone rocks/beds/intervals interleaved at outcrop scale with other subordinate siliciclastic rocks/beds/intervals.

concepts.label: sandstone + siltstone
concepts.definition: Sandstone and siltstone beds/intervals interleaved at outcrop scale.

concepts.label: sannaite
concepts.definition: A variety of lamprophyre composed of combinations of olivine, titanian augite, kaersutite and Ti-rich biotite phenocrysts with alkali feldspar dominating over plagioclase in the groundmass that also contains nepheline. Now defined in the lamprophyre classification (Table 2.9, p. 19). (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 139)

concepts.label: schist
concepts.definition: A metamorphic rock for which a protolith cannot be conclusively identified and displaying a schistose structure, i.e. a preferred orientation of inequant mineral grains or grain aggregates produced by metamorphic processes. A schist can be readily split into thin flakes or slabs because of the well-developed parallelism of more than 50% of the minerals present, particularly those of lamellar or elongate prismatic habit (e.g. mica and hornblende). For phyllosilicate-rich rocks the term schist is commonly used for medium- to coarse-grained varieties, whereas finer-grained rocks may be given more specific names such as slates or phyllites. Adapted from Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 193) and Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

concepts.label: schistose fault rock
concepts.definition: A fault rock that retains some fissility. In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for fault rocks for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established.

concepts.label: schistose granulite
concepts.definition: A high-grade metamorphic rock, with a granoblastic texture and in which Fe–Mg silicates are dominantly hydroxyl-free, feldspar is a critical phase, and primary muscovite is absent, and with a superimposed foliation. In GSWA usage, this term is reserved for a schist for which a protolith cannot be conclusively established. See also definition of schist/schistose structure in Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 193).

concepts.label: schistose hydrothermal rock
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed hydrothermal rock displaying a schistose structure. See also definition of schist/schistose structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 193).

concepts.label: schistose marble
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed sedimentary carbonate rock consisting of more than 50% volume of carbonate minerals (calcite and/or aragonite and/or dolomite) and displaying a schistose structure. See also definition of gneiss/gneissose structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 154–155).

concepts.label: schistose meta-iron formation
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed iron formation displaying a schistose structure, i.e. a schist derived from a chemical or biochemical sedimentary protolith containing at least 15% iron of sedimentary origin. See also definition of schist/schistose structure in Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 193).

concepts.label: schistose metacarbonatite
concepts.definition: A schist derived by metamorphism of an igneous protolith containing a modal amount of primary carbonate minerals greater than 50%. See also definition of schist/schistose structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 193).

concepts.label: schistose metachert
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed chert displaying a schistose structure, i.e. a schist derived from a chemical or biochemical sedimentary rock largely consisting of silica and/or quartz. See also definition of schist/schistose structure in Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 193).

concepts.label: schistose para-amphibolite (carbonate)
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed amphibole-rich rock derived from a sedimentary carbonate protolith and displaying a schistose structure. See also definition of gneiss/gneissose structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 154–155).

concepts.label: schistose para-amphibolite (siliciclastic)
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed amphibole-rich rock derived from a sedimentary siliciclastic protolith and displaying a schistose structure. See also definition of gneiss/gneissose structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 154–155).

concepts.label: sedimentary breccia
concepts.definition: A coarse epiclastic rock formed by lithification of angular gravel (in which 30% of large particles are greater than 2 mm). Breccia differs from conglomerate in that the fragments have sharp edges and unworn corners, and may originate as a result of sedimentary processes such as talus accumulation, disturbance during sedimentation (intraclastic breccia), or collapse of rock material (solution breccia, collapse breccia). Excludes breccias formed by volcaniclastic processes. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

concepts.label: sedimentary rock
concepts.definition: A rock of sedimentary but otherwise unspecified origin, i.e. a rock for which a clastic or chemical/biochemical derivation cannot be conclusively established (e.g. due to alteration or weathering).

concepts.label: sedimentary
concepts.definition: A group name for rocks of sedimentary but otherwise unspecified origin, i.e. a rock for which a clastic or chemical/biochemical derivation cannot be conclusively established.

concepts.label: semipelite
concepts.definition: A metamorphic rock that has a modal ratio of mica to quartz + feldspar intermediate between a pelite and a psammite (adapted from Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 194).

concepts.label: semipelitic gneiss
concepts.definition: Type of gneiss derived by metamorphism of a fine- to medium-grained sedimentary or metasedimentary protolith, and with a modal ratio of mica to quartz + feldspar intermediate between a pelite and a psammite. See also definition of gneiss/gneissose structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 154–155).

concepts.label: semipelitic granofels/hornfels
concepts.definition: Type of micaceous granofels/hornfels derived by (contact) metamorphism of a fine- to medium-grained sedimentary or metasedimentary protolith, and with a modal ratio of mica to quartz + feldspar intermediate between a pelite and a psammite. See also definition of granofels/granofelsic structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 156); hornfels are granofels formed by contact metamorphism (Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 159).

concepts.label: semipelitic migmatite
concepts.definition: Composite, micaceous silicate metamorphic rock derived from a fine- to medium-grained siliciclastic sedimentary or metasedimentary protolith, with a modal ratio of mica to quartz + feldspar intermediate between a pelite and a psammite, and pervasively heterogeneous on a meso- to megascopic scale. It typically consists of darker (melanosome) and lighter (leucosome) parts. The darker parts usually exhibit features of metamorphic rocks, whereas the lighter parts are of igneous appearance. See definition of migmatite in Fettes and Desmond (2007, p. 176).

concepts.label: semipelitic schist
concepts.definition: Type of schist derived by metamorphism of a fine- to medium-grained sedimentary or metasedimentary protolith, and with a modal ratio of mica to quartz + feldspar intermediate between a pelite and a psammite. See also definition of schist/schistose structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 193).

concepts.label: serpentinite derived from intrusive rock
concepts.definition: Metamorphic rock composed of more than 75% vol. of minerals of the serpentine group, and demonstrably derived from an igneous (intrusive or coarse-grained extrusive) protolith (adapted from Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 194).

concepts.label: serpentinite derived from volcanic rock
concepts.definition: Metamorphic rock composed of more than 75% vol. of minerals of the serpentine group, and demonstrably derived from an igneous extrusive protolith (adapted from Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 194).

concepts.label: shale
concepts.definition: A laminated, indurated very fine-grained rock with more than 66% clay-sized minerals; a claystone with fissility. GSWA now discourages the use of 'shale' as it is considered predominantly a textural term. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

concepts.label: shocked target rock
concepts.definition: Non-brecciated rocks showing unequivocal effects of shock metamorphism, exclusive of whole rock melting (Osinski et al., 2022).

concepts.label: siliceous sinter
concepts.definition: The lightweight porous opaline variety of silica, white or nearly white, deposited as an incrustation by precipitation from the waters of geysers and hot springs. The term has been applied loosely to any deposit made by a geyser or hot spring. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

concepts.label: siliciclastic gneiss
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed siliciclastic rock displaying a gneissose structure, i.e. a gneiss from a clastic sedimentary protolith and largely consisting of silicates and quartz. See also definition of gneiss/gneissose structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 154–155).

concepts.label: siliciclastic granofels/hornfels
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed siliciclastic rock displaying a granofelsic structure, i.e. a granofels/hornfels derived from a clastic sedimentary protolith and largely consisting of silicates and quartz. See also definition of granofels/granofelsic structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 156); hornfels are granofels formed by contact metamorphism (Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 159).

concepts.label: siliciclastic migmatite
concepts.definition: Composite silicate metamorphic rock derived from a siliciclastic protolith, pervasively heterogeneous on a meso- to megascopic scale. It typically consists of darker (melanosome) and lighter (leucosome) parts. The darker parts usually exhibit features of metamorphic rocks, whereas the lighter parts are of igneous appearance. Adapted from Fettes and Desmond (2007, p. 176).

concepts.label: siliciclastic rock
concepts.definition: A sedimentary rock that is silicon-bearing (in the form of quartz and silicates) and is composed principally of broken fragments that are derived from pre-existing rocks or minerals and that have been transported some distance from their places of origin, but otherwise uncategorized. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011)

concepts.label: siliciclastic rock; undivided
concepts.definition: A sedimentary rock that is silicon-bearing (in the form of quartz and silicates) and is composed principally of broken fragments that are derived from pre-existing rocks or minerals and that have been transported some distance from their places of origin, but otherwise uncategorized. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011). GSWA usage of this term is restricted to rocks that are partially weathered or are identified using remote sensing imagery, and the use of the related code/notation is limited to GSWA's Explanatory Notes System.

concepts.label: siliciclastic schist
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed siliciclastic rock displaying a schistose structure, i.e. a schist derived from a clastic sedimentary protolith and largely consisting of silicates and quartz. See also definition of schist/schistose structure in Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 193).

concepts.label: siliciclastic + lesser carbonate
concepts.definition: Siliciclastic rocks/beds/intervals and subordinate carbonate rocks/beds/intervals interleaved at outcrop scale.

concepts.label: silicified meta-igneous felsic rock
concepts.definition: An igneous felsic rock affected by silicification, i.e. hydrothermal alteration resulting in a net addition of silica to the rock, for which an intrusive, extrusive or volcaniclastic protolith cannot be conclusively identified. There is no implication on the timing of alteration relative to other metamorphic processes (e.g. regional metamorphism) that may have affected the rock.

concepts.label: silicified meta-igneous mafic rock
concepts.definition: An igneous mafic rock affected by silicification, i.e. hydrothermal alteration resulting in a net addition of silica to the rock, for which an intrusive, extrusive or volcaniclastic protolith cannot be conclusively identified. There is no implication on the timing of alteration relative to other metamorphic processes (e.g. regional metamorphism) that may have affected the rock.

concepts.label: silicified meta-iron formation
concepts.definition: An iron formation affected by silicification, i.e. hydrothermal alteration resulting in a net addition of silica to the rock. There is no implication on the timing of alteration relative to other metamorphic processes (e.g. regional metamorphism) that may have affected the rock.

concepts.label: silicified meta-ultramafic intrusive rock
concepts.definition: An ultramafic igneous (intrusive or coarse-grained extrusive) rock affected by silicification, i.e. hydrothermal alteration resulting in a net addition of silica to the rock. There is no implication on the timing of alteration relative to other metamorphic processes (e.g. regional metamorphism) that may have affected the rock.

concepts.label: silicified meta-ultramafic rock
concepts.definition: An ultramafic volcanic or volcaniclastic rock affected by silicification, i.e. hydrothermal alteration resulting in a net addition of silica to the rock. There is no implication on the timing of alteration relative to other metamorphic processes (e.g. regional metamorphism) that may have affected the rock.

concepts.label: silicified metacarbonatite
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed carbonatite affected by silicification, i.e. hydrothermal alteration resulting in a net addition of silica to the rock. There is no implication on the timing of alteration relative to other metamorphic processes (e.g. regional metamorphism) that may have affected the rock.

concepts.label: silicified metachert
concepts.definition: A chert affected by silicification, i.e. hydrothermal alteration resulting in a net addition of silica to the rock. There is no implication on the timing of alteration relative to other metamorphic processes (e.g. regional metamorphism) that may have affected the rock.

concepts.label: silicified metaconglomerate
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed conglomerate affected by silicification, i.e. hydrothermal alteration resulting in a net addition of silica to the rock. There is no implication on the timing of alteration relative to other metamorphic processes (e.g. regional metamorphism) that may have affected the rock.

concepts.label: silicified metafelsic volcanic rock
concepts.definition: A felsic igneous volcanic rock affected by silicification, i.e. hydrothermal alteration resulting in a net addition of silica to the rock. There is no implication on the timing of alteration relative to other metamorphic processes (e.g. regional metamorphism) that may have affected the rock. GSWA usage restricts the term to those occurrences whereby a more specific lithology (e.g. metarhyolite) cannot be identified. GSWA's rock classification scheme prefers the use of volcanic terminology for any igneous rock formed on or near the Earth's surface, i.e. for those hypabyssal or subvolcanic rocks such as dykes, sills, and cryptodomes that are demonstrably both spatially and temporally associated with extrusive volcanic rocks.

concepts.label: silicified metagranitic rock
concepts.definition: A felsic intrusive rock affected by silicification, i.e. hydrothermal alteration resulting in a net addition of silica to the rock. There is no implication on the timing of alteration relative to other metamorphic processes (e.g. regional metamorphism) that may have affected the rock. GSWA usage restricts the term to those occurrences whereby a more specific lithology (e.g. metasyenite) cannot be identified.

concepts.label: silicified metamafic intrusive rock
concepts.definition: A mafic intrusive rock affected by silicification, i.e. hydrothermal alteration resulting in a net addition of silica to the rock. There is no implication on the timing of alteration relative to other metamorphic processes (e.g. regional metamorphism) that may have affected the rock. GSWA usage restricts the term to those occurrences whereby a more specific lithology (e.g. metagabbro) cannot be identified.

concepts.label: silicified metamafic volcanic rock
concepts.definition: A mafic volcanic rock affected by silicification, i.e. hydrothermal alteration resulting in a net addition of silica to the rock. There is no implication on the timing of alteration relative to other metamorphic processes (e.g. regional metamorphism) that may have affected the rock. GSWA usage restricts the term to those occurrences whereby a more specific lithology (e.g. metabasalt) cannot be identified.

concepts.label: silicified metasiliciclastic rock
concepts.definition: A siliciclastic rock affected by silicification, i.e. hydrothermal alteration resulting in a net addition of silica to the rock. There is no implication on the timing of alteration relative to other metamorphic processes (e.g. regional metamorphism) that may have affected the rock.

concepts.label: silicified metavolcanic or metavolcaniclastic rock
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed volcanic or volcaniclastic rock otherwise uncategorized and affected by silicification, i.e. hydrothermal alteration resulting in a net addition of silica to the rock. There is no implication on the timing of alteration relative to other metamorphic processes (e.g. regional metamorphism) that may have affected the rock.

concepts.label: silicified pelite
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed fine-grained siliciclastic rock, otherwise uncategorized, affected by silicification, i.e. hydrothermal alteration resulting in a net addition of silica to the rock. There is no implication on the timing of alteration relative to other metamorphic processes (e.g. regional metamorphism) that may have affected the rock.

concepts.label: silicified psammite and pelite; interlayered
concepts.definition: A succession of sandstone and mudstone beds affected by silicification, i.e. hydrothermal alteration resulting in a net addition of silica to the rock. There is no implication on the timing of alteration relative to other metamorphic processes (e.g. regional metamorphism) that may have affected the rock.

concepts.label: silicified semipelite
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed fine- to medium-grained siliciclastic rock, otherwise uncategorized, affected by silicification, i.e. hydrothermal alteration resulting in a net addition of silica to the rock. There is no implication on the timing of alteration relative to other metamorphic processes (e.g. regional metamorphism) that may have affected the rock.

concepts.label: siltstone
concepts.definition: An indurated mud in which silt predominates over clay (clay less than 66%). Siltstone has the grain size and composition of shale but lacks its fine lamination or fissility; it tends to be flaggy, containing hard, durable, generally thin layers, and commonly shows various primary current structures. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

concepts.label: siltstone + sandstone
concepts.definition: Siltstone and sandstone beds/intervals interleaved at outcrop scale.

concepts.label: slate
concepts.definition: Ultrafine- or very fine-grained metamorphic rock displaying slaty cleavage, i.e. a type of continuous cleavage in which the individual grains are too small to be seen by the unaided eye. Slate is usually of very low metamorphic grade, although it may also occur under low-grade conditions. (Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p.–195)

concepts.label: spessartite
concepts.definition: A variety of lamprophyre consisting of phenocrysts of hornblende with or without biotite, olivine or pyroxene in a groundmass of the same minerals plus plagioclase and subordinate alkali feldspar. Now defined in the lamprophyre classification (Table 2.9, p. 19). (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 144)

concepts.label: spongolite/spicularite
concepts.definition: A sediment or rock composed principally of the remains of sponges. A sediment predominantly composed of discrete spicules is termed a spicularite, whereas one predominantly composed of rigid bodied sponges is termed a spongolite. Adapted from Gammon (1978) and Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

concepts.label: stromatoporoid dolomite
concepts.definition: A dolomite rock distinguished by the presence of stromatoporoids, i.e. extinct sessile, benthic, reef-forming sponges with calcareous skeletons that were especially abundant from the Paleozoic to the Cretaceous periods.

concepts.label: stromatoporoid limestone
concepts.definition: A limestone distinguished by the presence of stromatoporoids, i.e. extinct sessile, benthic, reef-forming sponges with calcareous skeletons that were especially abundant from the Paleozoic to the Cretaceous periods.

concepts.label: sub-bituminous coal
concepts.definition: A black coal, intermediate in rank between lignite and bituminous coals or, in some classifications, the equivalent of black lignite. It is distinguished from lignite by higher carbon and lower moisture content. Further classification of sub-bituminous coal is made on the basis of calorific value. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

concepts.label: subarkose
concepts.definition: An arenite that does not have enough feldspar to be classed as an arkose, or that is intermediate in composition between arkose and quartzarenite. Subarkose specifically contains 75–95% quartz and chert, and 5–25% unstable materials in which the ratio of feldspar:lithic grains is greater than 1:1. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

concepts.label: sublitharenite
concepts.definition: An arenite that is intermediate in composition between a litharenite and a quartzarenite; specifically containing 5–25% rock/lithic grains and a feldspar:lithic ratio less than 1:1. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

concepts.label: suevite
concepts.definition: Polymictic impact breccia with particulate matrix containing lithic and mineral clasts in all stages of shock metamorphism including cogenetic impact melt particles, which are in a glassy or crystallized state (Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 198).

concepts.label: syenite
concepts.definition: An intrusive rock consisting mainly of alkali feldspar with subordinate sodic plagioclase, biotite, pyroxene, amphibole and occasional fayalite. Minor quartz or nepheline may also be present. Now defined modally in QAPF field 7 (Fig. 2.4, p. 22). (cf. Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 145)

concepts.label: syenogranite
concepts.definition: An optional term for a variety of granite in QAPF field 3a (Fig. 2.4, p. 22) consisting of alkali feldspar with subordinate plagioclase (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 146).

concepts.label: tektite
concepts.definition: Impact glass formed at terrestrial impact craters from melt ejected ballistically and deposited as aerodynamically shaped bodies in a strewn field outside the continuous ejecta blanket. The size of tektites ranges from the submillimetre range (microtektites, generally found in deep sea sediments) to the subdecimetre range, rarely to decimetres. (Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p.  200)

concepts.label: tonalite
concepts.definition: An intrusive rock consisting essentially of quartz and intermediate plagioclase, usually with biotite and amphibole. Now defined modally in QAPF field 5 (Fig. 2.4, p. 22). (cf. Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 149)

concepts.label: tourmaline vein
concepts.definition: A rock comprising tourmaline crystals of pegmatitic or hydrothermal origin, as vein-filling material.

concepts.label: trachyte
concepts.definition: A volcanic rock consisting essentially of alkali feldspar. Now defined modally in QAPF field 7 (Fig. 2.11, p. 31) and, if modes are not available, chemically in TAS field T (Fig. 2.14, p. 35). Definition from Le Maitre et al. (2005, p. 151). GSWA's rock classification scheme prefers the use of volcanic terminology for any igneous rock formed on or near the Earth's surface, i.e. for those hypabyssal or subvolcanic rocks such as dykes, sills, and cryptodomes that are demonstrably both spatially and temporally associated with extrusive volcanic rocks.

concepts.label: travertine
concepts.definition: Biotically and/or abiotically precipitated calcium carbonate (predominantly calcite and aragonite) from spring-fed, heated and/or ambient-temperature waters. The spongy or less compact variety is named tufa. Adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

concepts.label: troctolite
concepts.definition: A variety of gabbro composed essentially of highly calcic plagioclase and olivine with little or no pyroxene. Now defined modally in the gabbroic rock classification (Fig. 2.6, p. 25). (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 151)

concepts.label: trondhjemite
concepts.definition: A leucocratic variety of tonalite consisting essentially of sodic plagioclase and quartz with minor biotite. Orthoclase is characteristically absent and hornblende is rare. May be used as a synonym for plagiogranite and leucocratic tonalite of QAPF field 5 (p. 23). (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 152)

concepts.label: ultracataclasite
concepts.definition: A cohesive fault rock with a poorly developed or absent schistosity, characterized by generally angular porphyroclasts and lithic fragments in a finer-grained matrix of similar composition that constitutes more than 90% of the rock volume. Definition adapted from Fossen (2016) and Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 202).

concepts.label: ultramafic gneiss derived from intrusive rock
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed ultramafic igneous (intrusive or coarse-grained extrusive) rock displaying a gneissose structure, i.e. a gneiss derived from an intrusive rock with one or more mafic minerals as the main component(s). See also definition of gneiss/gneissose structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 154–155).

concepts.label: ultramafic gneiss; volcanic or undivided
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed ultramafic volcanic or volcaniclastic rock displaying a gneissose structure, i.e. a gneiss derived from an extrusive or related rock with one or more mafic minerals as the main component(s). See also definition of gneiss/gneissose structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 154–155).

concepts.label: ultramafic granofels/hornfels derived from intrusive rock
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed ultramafic igneous (intrusive or coarse-grained extrusive) rock displaying a granofelsic structure, i.e. a granofels/hornfels derived from an intrusive rock with one or more mafic minerals as the main components (adapted from Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 202). See also definition of granofels/granofelsic structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 156); hornfels are granofels formed by contact metamorphism (Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 159).

concepts.label: ultramafic granofels/hornfels; volcanic or undivided
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed ultramafic volcanic or volcaniclastic rock displaying a granofelsic structure, i.e. a granofels/hornfels derived from an extrusive or related rock with one or more mafic minerals as the main components (adapted from Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 202). See also definition of granofels/granofelsic structure in Fettes and Desmons (2007, p. 156); hornfels are granofels formed by contact metamorphism (Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 159).

concepts.label: ultramafic intrusive rock
concepts.definition: Originally a term for a rock consisting essentially of mafic minerals, e.g. peridotite, dunite. Now defined as a rock with M>90%. Adapted from Le Maitre et al. (2005, p. 21 and p. 153).

concepts.label: ultramafic intrusive rock; undivided
concepts.definition: A demonstrably ultramafic (M>90%) intrusive rock, otherwise uncategorized. GSWA usage of this term is restricted to rocks that are partially weathered or are identified using remote sensing imagery, and the use of the related code/notation is limited to GSWA's Explanatory Notes System.

concepts.label: ultramafic schist derived from intrusive rock
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed ultramafic igneous (intrusive or coarse-grained extrusive) rock displaying a schistose structure, i.e. a schist derived from an intrusive rock with one or more mafic minerals as the main component(s). See also definition of schist/schistose structure in Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 193).

concepts.label: ultramafic schist; volcanic or undivided
concepts.definition: A metamorphosed ultramafic volcanic or volcaniclastic rock displaying a schistose structure, i.e. a schist derived from an intrusive rock with one or more mafic minerals as the main component(s). See also definition of schist/schistose structure in Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p. 193).

concepts.label: ultramafic volcanic rock
concepts.definition: An igneous volcanic rock composed chiefly of one or more ferromagnesian, dark-coloured minerals in its mode (adapted from Glossary of geology, 5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011). Originally a term for a rock consisting essentially of mafic minerals, e.g. peridotite, dunite. Now defined as a rock with M greater than 90% (section 2.11.2, p. 28), where M represents the volume modal percentage of mafic and related minerals (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 4 and 153). GSWA's rock classification scheme prefers the use of volcanic terminology for any igneous rock formed on or near the Earth's surface, i.e. for those hypabyssal or subvolcanic rocks such as dykes, sills, and cryptodomes that are demonstrably both spatially and temporally associated with extrusive volcanic rocks.

concepts.label: ultramafic volcanic rock; undivided
concepts.definition: A demonstrably ultramafic igneous volcanic rock, otherwise uncategorized. GSWA usage of this term is restricted to rocks that are partially weathered or are identified using remote sensing imagery, and the use of the related code/notation is limited to GSWA's Explanatory Notes System. GSWA's rock classification scheme prefers the use of volcanic terminology for any igneous rock formed on or near the Earth's surface, i.e. for those hypabyssal or subvolcanic rocks such as dykes, sills, and cryptodomes that are demonstrably both spatially and temporally associated with extrusive volcanic rocks.

concepts.label: ultramafic volcaniclastic breccia
concepts.definition: A volcaniclastic rock composed mostly of angular fragments greater than 2 mm in size consisting of either (a) pyroclastic detritus or (b) terrigenous volcanic detritus of epiclastic origin, and with an overall ultramafic composition. 'Volcaniclastic' includes all clastic volcanic materials formed by any process of fragmentation, dispersed by any kind of transporting agent, deposited in any environment, or mixed in any significant portion with non-volcanic fragments.

concepts.label: ultramafic volcaniclastic breccia-sandstone
concepts.definition: A volcaniclastic rock composed mostly of angular fragments ranging in size from sand (0.0625 – 2 mm) and above, consisting of either (a) pyroclastic detritus or (b) terrigenous volcanic detritus of epiclastic origin, and with an overall ultramafic composition. 'Volcaniclastic' includes all clastic volcanic materials formed by any process of fragmentation, dispersed by any kind of transporting agent, deposited in any environment, or mixed in any significant portion with non-volcanic fragments.

concepts.label: ultramafic volcaniclastic conglomerate
concepts.definition: A conglomerate consisting of either (a) pyroclastic detritus or (b) terrigenous volcanic detritus of epiclastic origin, and with an overall ultramafic composition. 'Volcaniclastic' includes all clastic volcanic materials formed by any process of fragmentation, dispersed by any kind of transporting agent, deposited in any environment, or mixed in any significant portion with non-volcanic fragments.

concepts.label: ultramafic volcaniclastic granule/pebble breccia
concepts.definition: A breccia composed mostly of angular fragments ranging in size from granule (2–4 mm) to pebble (4–32 mm) consisting of either (a) pyroclastic detritus or (b) terrigenous volcanic detritus of epiclastic origin, and with an overall ultramafic composition. 'Volcaniclastic' includes all clastic volcanic materials formed by any process of fragmentation, dispersed by any kind of transporting agent, deposited in any environment, or mixed in any significant portion with non-volcanic fragments.

concepts.label: ultramafic volcaniclastic mudstone
concepts.definition: A mudstone (grain size ranging from silt to clay, i.e. less than 0.0625 mm) consisting of either (a) pyroclastic detritus or (b) terrigenous volcanic detritus of epiclastic origin, and with an overall mafic composition. 'Volcaniclastic' includes all clastic volcanic materials formed by any process of fragmentation, dispersed by any kind of transporting agent, deposited in any environment, or mixed in any significant portion with non-volcanic fragments.

concepts.label: ultramafic volcaniclastic rock
concepts.definition: A volcaniclastic rock consisting of either (a) pyroclastic detritus or (b) terrigenous volcanic detritus of epiclastic origin and with an overall mafic composition, but otherwise uncategorized. 'Volcaniclastic' includes all clastic volcanic materials formed by any process of fragmentation, dispersed by any kind of transporting agent, deposited in any environment, or mixed in any significant portion with non-volcanic fragments.

concepts.label: ultramafic volcaniclastic sandstone
concepts.definition: A sandstone (grain size 0.0625 – 2 mm) consisting of either (a) pyroclastic detritus or (b) terrigenous volcanic detritus of epiclastic origin, and with an overall ultramafic composition. 'Volcaniclastic' includes all clastic volcanic materials formed by any process of fragmentation, dispersed by any kind of transporting agent, deposited in any environment, or mixed in any significant portion with non-volcanic fragments.

concepts.label: ultramafic volcaniclastic sandstone-siltstone
concepts.definition: A volcaniclastic rock composed mostly of fragments ranging in size from sand (0.0625 – 2 mm) to silt (0.0039 – 0.0625 mm) of either (a) pyroclastic detritus or (b) terrigenous volcanic detritus of epiclastic origin, and with an overall ultramafic composition. 'Volcaniclastic' includes all clastic volcanic materials formed by any process of fragmentation, dispersed by any kind of transporting agent, deposited in any environment, or mixed in any significant portion.

concepts.label: ultramafic volcaniclastic sediment-matrix breccia
concepts.definition: A commonly monomictic breccia of overall ultramafic composition composed of angular, coarse igneous fragments cemented by a fine-grained matrix that is clastic though not necessarily strictly sedimentary in origin. 'Volcaniclastic' includes all clastic volcanic materials formed by any process of fragmentation, dispersed by any kind of transporting agent, deposited in any environment, or mixed in any significant portion with non-volcanic fragments.

concepts.label: ultramylonite
concepts.definition: Mylonite in which more than 90% of the rock volume has undergone grain-size reduction (Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p.  202); a mylonite with over 90% matrix and less than 10% porphyroclasts (Passchier and Trouw, 2005).

concepts.label: unknown lithology
concepts.definition: A rock so altered, weathered or of such a fine grain size that an inference on the protolith or origin of the rock cannot be made. Also used to allocate a lithology to sample legacy data where a lithology was not known. The use of the related code/notation is limited to GSWA's Field observation database (WAROX).

concepts.label: unknown
concepts.definition: A group name for lithologies so altered, weathered or of such a fine grain size that an inference on the protolith or origin of the rock cannot be made. Also used to allocate a lithology to sample legacy data where a lithology was not known. The use of the related code/notation is limited to GSWA's Field observation database (WAROX).

concepts.label: vein
concepts.definition: A distinct sheet-like body of crystallized minerals within a rock. Veins form when mineral constituents carried by an aqueous solution within the rock mass are deposited through precipitation. The hydraulic flow involved is usually due to hydrothermal circulation. (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vein_(geology)).

concepts.label: vogesite
concepts.definition: A variety of lamprophyre in which amphibole is more abundant than biotite and alkali feldspar is more abundant than plagioclase. Augite is frequently present. Now defined in the lamprophyre classification (Table 2.9, p. 19). (Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 155)

concepts.label: volcanic rock
concepts.definition: A rock of igneous volcanic/extrusive origin but commonly too weathered to make further distinctions.

concepts.label: igneous volcanic
concepts.definition: A group name for rock types of igneous extrusive (or volcanic) origin.

concepts.label: websterite
concepts.definition: A variety of pyroxenite consisting largely of varying amounts of orthopyroxene and clinopyroxene, with less than 10% olivine. Now defined modally in the ultramafic rock classification (Fig. 2.9, p. 28). Adapted from Le Maitre et al. (2005, p. 156).

concepts.label: wehrlite
concepts.definition: An ultramafic intrusive rock composed of olivine and clinopyroxene often with minor brown hornblende. Now defined modally in the ultramafic rock classification (Fig. 2.9, p. 28). (cf. Le Maitre et al., 2005, p. 156)

concepts.label: xenolith- or inclusion-bearing lithology
concepts.definition: A prefix used in GSWA's Explanatory Notes system (ENS) to characterize mixed lithological types (metamorphosed or not), where the first code represents the host rock lithology and the second code represents the dominant lithology of the xenolith/inclusions.

concepts.label: xenolith- or inclusion-bearing
concepts.definition: A prefix used in GSWA's Explanatory Notes system (ENS) to characterize mixed rock types (metamorphosed or not) where one of the component is a xenolith or inclusion.

concepts.label: metamorphic: protolith unknown
concepts.definition: A group name for metamorphosed rocks for which the protolith cannot be identified.
